greek.name: Greek & Roman Mythology
greek.description: One of the most influential mythological systems in Western history, featuring the Olympian gods and their numerous offspring

deities.name: Zeus / Jupiter
deities.significance: King of the Olympian gods and ruler of the sky. Zeus was the most powerful deity in Greek religion, representing law, justice, and divine authority. His worship was central to Greek civilization.
deities.impact: Zeus profoundly influenced Greek culture through worship cults, athletic competitions like the Olympic Games, and myths establishing moral lessons. His authority provided a template for human kingship.
deities.alterEgos: Swan (to seduce Leda), Bull (to abduct Europa), Eagle (divine form), Golden Shower (to reach Danaë), Serpent (to seduce Persephone), Mortal man (various human forms)
deities.relationships: Wife: Hera (stormy marriage due to infidelities). Lovers: Leda, Europa, Danaë, Io, Semele, Metis. Children with multiple goddesses and mortals. Major rivalry with Ares. Strong mentoring with Athena and Apollo. Conflict with Prometheus.
deities.powers: Thunderbolt projection, lightning summoning, weather control, shape-shifting, teleportation, superhuman strength, immortality, omniscience
deities.temples: Temple of Zeus at Olympia (housed colossal gold-ivory statue), Zeus Xenios temples throughout Greece, temples in Athens, Thebes, Crete, Rome
deities.worshipers: Nearly universal among Greeks and Romans - estimated tens of millions at peak
deities.history: Worship from Mycenaean period (1600-1100 BCE), central to classical Greek religion (500-323 BCE), adopted by Romans as Jupiter

deities.name: Hera / Juno
deities.significance: Queen of Olympian gods and goddess of marriage, family, and women. Represented the sacred bond of marriage and protection of women and children.
deities.impact: Hera cults emphasized family values. Her jealousy narratives reflected real-world marriage complexities. Peacock symbolism became iconic in Mediterranean art.
deities.alterEgos: Iris (messenger form), Peacock (sacred animal manifestation), Protector of the Hearth (domestic form)
deities.relationships: Husband: Zeus (stormy due to infidelities). Protective of young women and pregnant mothers. Bitter rivalries with Zeus's lovers and illegitimate children.
deities.powers: Divine authority, curse casting, punishment of oath-breakers, control over marriage bonds, weather influence, shapeshifting
deities.temples: Heraeum in Argos, Heraeum in Olympia, temples throughout Greece
deities.worshipers: Estimated 10-15 million at peak, particularly women
deities.history: Worship from Early Bronze Age, central to Greek religion, widely worshipped in Rome as Juno

deities.name: Poseidon / Neptune
deities.significance: God of seas, earthquakes, and horses. One of twelve major Olympians with immense power over maritime civilization.
deities.impact: Poseidon worship was vital for sailors, fishermen, and traders. Temples stood near harbors throughout Greece.
deities.alterEgos: Horse (to seduce Medusa and Demeter), Dolphin (to guide sailors), Stallion (equine form), Earthquake (destructive force)
deities.relationships: Wife: Amphitrite. Lover of Medusa. Pursued Demeter (rejected). Complicated relationship with Athens. Punished Odysseus.
deities.powers: Earthquake creation, tsunami generation, weather control, horse mastery, shapeshifting, trident magic
deities.temples: Poseidon Temple in Sounion, temples in Corinth, Athens, Isthmia
deities.worshipers: Estimated 8-12 million at peak, particularly sailors and fishermen
deities.history: Worship from Mycenaean period, central to seafaring civilization

deities.name: Hades / Pluto
deities.significance: God of the Underworld and the dead, ruling all souls who died. Despite his dark domain, Hades was not evil but impartial.
deities.impact: Hades cults, particularly the Eleusinian Mysteries, offered secret knowledge about the afterlife.
deities.alterEgos: Pluto (wealth manifestation), Invisible King (helmet of invisibility), Judge of the Dead (judicial form)
deities.relationships: Wife: Persephone (abducted but eventually loved). Brothers: Zeus and Poseidon. Close with Hermes.
deities.powers: Death control, soul command, wealth manipulation, invisibility (helmet), immortality
deities.temples: Temples at Hermione, Acheron, honored through Eleusinian Mysteries
deities.worshipers: Estimated 5-8 million at peak, less widely worshipped due to fear
deities.history: Worship from Mycenaean period, central to mystery religions

deities.name: Demeter / Ceres
deities.significance: Goddess of agriculture, grain, and harvest. Represented fertility and humanity's dependence on agriculture.
deities.impact: Demeter's myth explained seasonal cycles. Eleusinian Mysteries became most important Greek religious rite.
deities.alterEgos: Chloé (green sprout form), Wheat Goddess (grain manifestation), Mother of Abundance (fertility form)
deities.relationships: Daughter: Persephone (devoted, abduction caused devastating famine). Sister: Hestia, Hera, Zeus.
deities.powers: Crop growth and control, famine creation, fertility granting, seasonal cycle manipulation
deities.temples: Eleusinian Sanctuary (most sacred), temples at Eleusis, Enna
deities.worshipers: Estimated 10-15 million at peak, particularly farmers
deities.history: Worship from Mycenaean period, central to agricultural society

deities.name: Athena / Minerva
deities.significance: Goddess of wisdom, warfare strategy, and craft skills. Represented intellectual pursuits and practical arts.
deities.impact: Athena's patronage of Athens made her central to Greek civilization's identity. The Parthenon honored her.
deities.alterEgos: Pallas (warrior form), Parthenos (maiden form), Craftswoman (artisan aspect)
deities.relationships: Father: Zeus (born from his head). Mentor/Patron: Heracles, Perseus, Odysseus.
deities.powers: Strategic warfare guidance, craft mastery, wisdom granting, weaving magic, owl communication
deities.temples: Parthenon in Athens (most famous), Athena Nike temple, temples throughout Greece
deities.worshipers: Estimated 12-18 million at peak, particularly in Athens
deities.history: Worship from Mycenaean period, central to Athenian identity

deities.name: Apollo / Phoebus
deities.significance: God of sun, music, healing, prophecy, and poetry. Represented order, beauty, and rational thought.
deities.impact: Apollo's Oracles at Delphi were most consulted prophecy sources in ancient world.
deities.alterEgos: Phoebus (sun chariot driver), Healer (medical form), The Oracle (prophetic aspect)
deities.relationships: Mother: Leto. Twin Sister: Artemis (closest bond). Many lovers: Daphne, Coronis, Hyacinthus.
deities.powers: Sun control and movement, prophecy granting, music inspiration, plague summoning, healing abilities
deities.temples: Temple of Apollo at Delphi (most important), Temple in Corinth, temples at Delos
deities.history: Worship from Mycenaean period, Oracle at Delphi operated for 1000+ years

deities.name: Artemis / Diana
deities.significance: Goddess of hunt, moon, virginity, and young women. Represented independence and divine feminine autonomy.
deities.impact: Artemis cults provided space for women outside patriarchal structures. Her identity as hunter challenged gender norms.
deities.alterEgos: Diana (Roman form), Hecate (triple goddess form), Huntress (predatory aspect)
deities.relationships: Twin Brother: Apollo (closest bond). Father: Zeus. Mother: Leto.
deities.powers: Hunting mastery, moon control, animal communication, forest control, childbirth protection
deities.temples: Temple of Artemis at Ephesus (one of Seven Wonders), temples in Athens, Sparta
deities.worshipers: Estimated 10-15 million at peak, particularly young women and hunters
deities.history: Worship from Mycenaean period, Temple at Ephesus burned multiple times

deities.name: Aphrodite / Venus
deities.significance: Goddess of love, beauty, desire, and procreation. Represented power of attraction and sexuality.
deities.impact: Aphrodite worship celebrated sexuality and beauty. Her myths explored love complexities.
deities.alterEgos: Venus (Roman form), Goddess of Procreation (fertility aspect), Seductress (desire form)
deities.relationships: Husband: Hephaestus (arranged). Lover: Ares. Children: Eros, Aeneas.
deities.powers: Love inducement, beauty enhancement, desire manipulation, fertility granting
deities.temples: Sanctuary in Paphos (birthplace), temples in Corinth, Athens
deities.history: Worship from Bronze Age, central to Greek and Roman culture

deities.name: Ares / Mars
deities.significance: God of war, violence, and bloodlust. Embodied brutal, chaotic aspects of warfare.
deities.impact: Ares represented warfare's dark side Greeks tried to minimize. Mars received greater veneration in Rome.
deities.alterEgos: Mars (Roman form), Bloodlust personified (primal violent form), Plague-Bringer (disease form)
deities.relationships: Parents: Zeus and Hera (strained). Lover: Aphrodite. Siblings: Hephaestus (opposed), Athena (rivalry).
deities.powers: Bloodlust inducement, warfare frenzy granting, battle control, violence inspiration
deities.temples: Temple of Ares in Athens, temples throughout Greece, Mars temples in Rome
deities.worshipers: Estimated 5-8 million at peak, primarily warriors
deities.history: Worship from Mycenaean period, less revered in Greece than Rome

deities.name: Hephaestus / Vulcan
deities.significance: God of fire, metalwork, blacksmiths, and craftsmanship. Represented human ingenuity.
deities.impact: Hephaestus inspired reverence for craftspeople. His myths elevated manual labor as divine.
deities.alterEgos: Craftsman Divine (artisan form), Fire Elemental (fire aspect), Master Engineer (inventor)
deities.relationships: Wife: Aphrodite (unfaithful). Parents: Zeus and Hera (neglectful). Close with Athena.
deities.powers: Forge mastery, automatic creation, fire control, metalworking magic, invention
deities.temples: Hephaesteum in Athens, temples throughout Greece
deities.worshipers: Estimated 3-5 million at peak, particularly blacksmiths
deities.history: Worship from Mycenaean period

deities.name: Hermes / Mercury
deities.significance: God of messengers, trade, travel, thieves, and boundaries. Represented communication and commerce.
deities.impact: Hermes's association with commerce made him patron of merchants. His trickster nature provided mythological explanations.
deities.alterEgos: Mercury (Roman form), Psychopomp (soul guide), Trickster (clever deceiver)
deities.relationships: Mother: Maia. Father: Zeus. Mentor: taught Heracles wrestling.
deities.powers: Instant travel and teleportation, merchant luck granting, theft mastery, soul guide authority
deities.temples: Herms (simple shrines), temples at Boundaries, throughout Greece
deities.history: Worship from Mycenaean period

deities.name: Hestia / Vesta
deities.significance: Goddess of hearth, home, and family. Represented stability and sacred center of every home.
deities.impact: Every Greek household maintained sacred hearth to Hestia, making her universally worshipped.
deities.alterEgos: Vesta (Roman form), Sacred Fire (elemental aspect), Home Guardian (protective)
deities.relationships: Siblings: Zeus, Hera, Demeter, Poseidon, Hades.
deities.powers: Home protection, hospitality enforcement, family harmony granting, fire tending
deities.temples: Sacred hearths in every home, Vestal Temple in Rome
deities.history: Worship from earliest tradition, central to household religion

deities.name: Dionysus / Bacchus
deities.significance: God of wine, festivity, theatre, and ecstatic experience. Represented liberation and celebration.
deities.impact: Dionysian festivals shaped Greek cultural life. He was patron of theatre and drama.
deities.alterEgos: Bacchus (Roman form), Wine Embodied (liquid form), Theater Master (artistic form)
deities.relationships: Mother: Semele (mortal). Father: Zeus. Stepmother: Hera. Romantic: married Ariadne.
deities.powers: Madness induction, intoxication granting, ecstatic state creation, grape/wine creation
deities.temples: Theater of Dionysus in Athens, temples at Delphi, throughout Greece
deities.history: Worship possibly from Thrace or Asia Minor, central to Greek culture

deities.name: Persephone / Proserpina
deities.significance: Goddess of spring, underworld, and regeneration. Embodied seasonal cycles.
deities.impact: Persephone's myth explained seasonal changes and provided solace to grieving.
deities.alterEgos: Proserpina (Roman form), Kore (maiden form), Queen of the Dead (underworld)
deities.relationships: Mother: Demeter (intensely protective). Husband: Hades (grew to love).
deities.powers: Vegetation control, seasonal manipulation, underworld rule, soul judgment
deities.temples: Eleusinian Sanctuary, temples at Enna, throughout agricultural regions
deities.history: Worship from Mycenaean period, central to Eleusinian Mysteries

deities.name: Heracles / Hercules
deities.significance: Greatest hero of Greek mythology. Son of Zeus and mortal woman. Performed Twelve Labors. Deified after death.
deities.impact: Heracles represented human strength and perseverance. His labors became moral templates. Most popular hero in Greek culture.
deities.alterEgos: Hercules (Roman form), Lion Slayer (after killing Nemean lion), Club-Bearer (weapon form)
deities.relationships: Father: Zeus. Mother: Alcmene. Wife: Hebe (goddess of youth). Mentor: Athena, Theseus ally.
deities.powers: Superhuman strength, invulnerability (mostly), lion-slaying, monster-slaying, shape-shifting
deities.temples: Heracles temples throughout Greece, especially in Thebes, Rome
deities.worshipers: Estimated 10-15 million at peak, especially warriors and athletes
deities.history: Worship from Mycenaean period, deified after death, athletic competitions honored him

deities.name: Perseus
deities.significance: Famous hero who slayed Medusa. Son of Zeus. Founder of Mycenae. Rescued Andromeda.
deities.impact: Perseus myth inspired countless works. His defeat of Medusa became iconic slaying story.
deities.alterEgos: Gorgon Slayer (after defeating Medusa), Shield-Bearer (using Medusa's head)
deities.relationships: Father: Zeus. Mother: Danaë. Wife: Andromeda. Mentor: Athena, Hermes.
deities.powers: Divine aid from gods, enhanced agility and strength, use of Medusa head (petrification power)
deities.temples: Temples throughout Greece, especially in Mycenae and Athens
deities.history: Mythological hero, foundational to Greek cultural identity

deities.name: Theseus
deities.significance: Hero of Athens. Slayed Minotaur. Founded many cities. Son of Poseidon or Aegeus.
deities.impact: Theseus became Athens's greatest hero. His labors rivaled Heracles. Symbol of Athenian power.
deities.alterEgos: Minotaur Slayer (after defeating the Minotaur), King of Athens (rulership)
deities.relationships: Father: Poseidon or Aegeus. Mother: Aethra. Ally: Heracles. Wife: Phaedra.
deities.powers: Enhanced strength and agility, labyrinth navigation, strategic thinking
deities.temples: Theseum in Athens, temples throughout Greece
deities.worshipers: Estimated 5-8 million at peak, especially in Athens
deities.history: Foundational to Athenian identity and Greek heroic tradition

deities.name: Asclepius
deities.significance: God of medicine and healing. Son of Apollo. Raised by Chiron. Could resurrect the dead.
deities.impact: Asclepius cults spread throughout Mediterranean. His rod became medical symbol worldwide.
deities.alterEgos: The Healer (medicinal form), Asclepion practitioner (at his healing temples)
deities.relationships: Father: Apollo. Mother: Coronis. Teacher: Chiron (centaur). Daughter: Hygieia.
deities.powers: Healing magic, resurrection, disease curing, medicine creation
deities.temples: Asclepieia (healing temples) throughout Greece, especially at Epidaurus
deities.worshipers: Estimated 8-12 million at peak, especially those seeking healing
deities.history: Worship from classical period, healing temples became ancient hospitals

greek.overview: Ancient Greek pantheon featuring powerful deities like Zeus, Athena, and Apollo. Rich with myths of heroes, monsters, and cosmic conflicts. Foundation of Western literature and philosophy.

norse.name: Norse Mythology
norse.description: Scandinavian mythology featuring the Aesir and Vanir gods, ending in Ragnarok

deities.name: Odin
deities.significance: All-Father and king of Aesir gods. God of wisdom, war, death, and magic. Willing to sacrifice anything for knowledge.
deities.impact: Odin's pursuit of wisdom influenced Norse values. Valkyrie concept came from his domain.
deities.alterEgos: Wodan (Germanic form), One-Eyed Wanderer (disguised form), Raven-Rider (animal form)
deities.relationships: Wife: Frigg. Sons: Thor, Baldur, Vidar, Vali. Allied with Loki despite betrayal. Mentor to warriors.
deities.powers: Rune magic, prophecy, poetry inspiration, shapeshifting, war and death control
deities.temples: Uppsala Temple (greatest Norse temple), temples throughout Scandinavia
deities.history: Indo-European warrior deity, worship strong in Viking Age

deities.name: Thor
deities.significance: God of thunder and strength. Immensely popular as protector against chaos. His hammer Mjolnir most powerful weapon.
deities.impact: Thor worship widespread among Norse. His hammer became iconic symbol.
deities.alterEgos: Thunder God (elemental form), Chariot-Rider (vehicle form), Red-Bearded Warrior
deities.relationships: Father: Odin. Mother: Frigg. Wife: Sif. Children: Modi, Magni. Close ally: Loki.
deities.powers: Thunder and lightning control, weather summoning, hammer mastery, superhuman strength
deities.temples: Temples throughout Scandinavia, especially Sweden and Norway
deities.history: Indo-European storm god, worship throughout Viking Age

deities.name: Loki
deities.significance: Trickster god whose actions lead to Ragnarok. Neither good nor evil, embodied unpredictability.
deities.impact: Loki's stories explained natural disasters. Complex, unpredictable figure.
deities.alterEgos: Salmon (fish form), Seal (marine form), Fly (insect form), Mare (horse form)
deities.relationships: Blood-brother: Odin. Friend/Rival: Thor. Wife: Sigyn. Children: Fenrir, Jormungandr, Hel.
deities.powers: Shapeshifting, deception magic, chaos summoning, fire control
deities.temples: No dedicated temples (feared), occasional small shrines
deities.worshipers: Limited direct worship, estimated 1-2 million for propitiation
deities.history: Ancient deity possibly pre-Norse origin, central to Norse mythology

deities.name: Freyja
deities.significance: Goddess of love, beauty, fertility, and war. Powerful and independent, claiming own share of slain in battle.
deities.impact: Freyja cults celebrated female power. Her necklace Brisingamen became symbol of beauty.
deities.alterEgos: Vanadis (lady form), Falcon-Flyer (bird form), War-Chooser (valkyrie aspect)
deities.relationships: Father: Njord. Brother: Freyr. Husband: Od. Children: Hnoss, Gersemi.
deities.powers: Love and desire inducement, fertility granting, falcon transformation, warrior blessing
deities.temples: Temples throughout Scandinavia especially Sweden
deities.history: Vanir goddess, worship throughout Viking Age

deities.name: Heimdall
deities.significance: Guardian of rainbow bridge Bifrost. Eternal watchman of gods. Sounds Gjallarhorn at Ragnarok.
deities.impact: Heimdall represented constant vigilance. Essential to cosmic order.
deities.alterEgos: Gjallarhorn-Blower (herald form), Rainbow-Walker (bridge form), Eternal Watcher
deities.relationships: Father: Odin. Enemy: Loki (will fight at Ragnarok). Ally: All Aesir gods.
deities.powers: Universal sight and hearing, Gjallarhorn mastery, bridge protection
deities.temples: Small shrines at boundaries, few dedicated temples
deities.history: Possibly Indo-European origin, became guardian figure

deities.name: Frigg
deities.significance: Queen of Aesir and goddess of marriage, motherhood, and household. Had own authority and servants.
deities.impact: Frigg's prominence showed importance of motherhood. Her fate knowledge made her nearly equal to Odin.
deities.alterEgos: Beloved (Odin's wife role), Mother of Baldur (maternal aspect), Fate-Keeper
deities.relationships: Husband: Odin. Son: Baldur. Handmaidens: served her.
deities.powers: Fate sight (though cannot prevent), household protection, motherhood power
deities.temples: Small shrines in villages, domestic worship
deities.history: Possibly pre-Indo-European mother goddess

deities.name: Baldur
deities.significance: Most beautiful and beloved of Aesir. Represented light, purity, and hope. Killed through Loki's trickery.
deities.impact: Baldur's death was most tragic event in Norse mythology. His return symbolizes renewal.
deities.alterEgos: Light Bringer (illumination form), Sacrificial Victim (death role)
deities.relationships: Parents: Odin and Frigg (deeply loved). Wife: Nanna. Blind brother: Hod (killed him).
deities.powers: Light radiance, beauty embodiment, joy inspiration
deities.temples: Few dedicated temples (prophesied to return), primarily religious significance
deities.worshipers: Estimated 4-6 million, less direct worship due to death and expected return
deities.history: Central to Norse apocalyptic cycle, death most significant event

deities.name: Tyr
deities.significance: God of war, justice, and heroic glory. Known for fairness and sacrifice for greater good (lost his hand binding Fenrir).
deities.impact: Tyr worship emphasized justice and fair dealings. Warrior who fights for principles.
deities.alterEgos: One-Handed Warrior (wounded form), Just Judge (judicial aspect)
deities.relationships: Father: Odin. Relationship with Fenrir: bound wolf at cost of hand.
deities.powers: Warfare mastery, justice enforcement, one-handed warrior strength, combat excellence
deities.temples: Temples throughout Scandinavia, especially warrior communities
deities.history: Ancient warrior deity, central to justice-based worship

norse.overview: Scandinavian mythology featuring Norse gods like Odin and Thor. Emphasizes honor, warrior culture, and the apocalyptic Ragnarok. Celebrates cosmology of multiple realms connected by Yggdrasil.

egyptian.name: Egyptian Mythology
egyptian.description: Ancient Egyptian pantheon spanning over 3000 years of civilization

deities.name: Ra
deities.significance: Sun god and creator deity. Traveled across sky daily and through underworld nightly. Central to Egyptian cosmology.
deities.impact: Ra's daily journey explained sun's movement. Pharaohs claimed incarnation from Ra.
deities.alterEgos: Khepri (scarab form - morning), Atum (evening form), Amun-Ra (combined form)
deities.relationships: Children: Shu and Tefnut. Relationship with Hathor (daughter and Eye). Battles with Apophis.
deities.powers: Solar radiation and heat control, light creation, daily sky journey, omniscient sight
deities.temples: Great Temple of Ra at Heliopolis (most important), temples throughout Egypt
deities.worshipers: Universal in ancient Egypt - estimated 8-10 million at peak
deities.history: Worship from Old Kingdom (2686-2181 BCE) through Greco-Roman period

deities.name: Osiris
deities.significance: God of afterlife, resurrection, and agriculture. Died and resurrected, becoming template for Egyptian afterlife beliefs.
deities.impact: Osiris's resurrection myth gave Egyptians hope for life after death. All pharaohs identified with Osiris.
deities.alterEgos: Khenti-Amenitiu (foremost of the Westerners), Green God (vegetation form)
deities.relationships: Wife: Isis (devoted partnership). Brother: Set (murdered him). Son: Horus.
deities.powers: Death control, soul judgment, resurrection teaching, fertility promotion
deities.temples: Temple at Abydos (primary pilgrimage site), temples at Karnak, Luxor
deities.history: Worship from Old Kingdom through Greco-Roman period

deities.name: Isis
deities.significance: Goddess of magic, healing, motherhood, and fertility. Devoted to Osiris, used magic to restore him.
deities.impact: Isis worship spread throughout Mediterranean, becoming most popular deity.
deities.alterEgos: Great of Magic (sorcerer form), Mother of Horus (protector form)
deities.relationships: Husband: Osiris. Son: Horus. Sister: Nephthys. Brother: Set (enemy).
deities.powers: Magic mastery, healing abilities, resurrection magic, child protection
deities.temples: Temple at Dendera, temples at Philae, Luxor, throughout Egypt and Mediterranean
deities.worshipers: Estimated 12-18 million at peak including Mediterranean
deities.history: Worship from Old Kingdom through Roman period

deities.name: Horus
deities.significance: Falcon god and son of Osiris. Fought uncle Set for throne. His Eye became symbol of wholeness.
deities.impact: Horus's claim justified pharaonic rule. His eye symbolism became protective amulets.
deities.alterEgos: Horus the Elder (sky form), Young Horus (child form), Falcon-Warrior
deities.relationships: Father: Osiris. Mother: Isis. Uncle: Set (bitter enemy).
deities.powers: Falcon sight mastery, sky control, eye symbolism and healing, royal authority
deities.temples: Horus Temple at Edfu, temples throughout Egypt
deities.history: Worship from Old Kingdom, Edfu temple major pilgrimage destination

deities.name: Anubis
deities.significance: God of mummification, embalming, and the dead. Originally primary god of dead before Osiris.
deities.impact: Anubis's role in mummification made him essential to burial practices.
deities.alterEgos: Inpu (original form), Guardian of Tombs (protective role), Jackal-Form
deities.relationships: Father: Osiris. Mother: Nephthys. Ally: Isis (worked in mummification).
deities.powers: Mummification magic, tomb protection, corpse preservation, afterlife guidance
deities.temples: Temples at Abydos, Saqqara, throughout Egypt in necropolises
deities.history: Worship from Old Kingdom through Greco-Roman period

deities.name: Thoth
deities.significance: God of wisdom, writing, and magic. Divine scribe and record-keeper. Invented writing and mathematics.
deities.impact: Thoth's association with writing made him patron of scribes and scholars.
deities.alterEgos: Ibis-Headed Scribe (bird form), Lunar Deity (moon aspect)
deities.relationships: Judge of the dead. Ally: other wisdom deities. Relationship with Seshat (goddess of writing).
deities.powers: Magic mastery, writing and knowledge granting, judgment authority, record-keeping power
deities.temples: Temples at Hermopolis, throughout Egypt especially in writing centers
deities.worshipers: Estimated 5-8 million at peak, especially scribes
deities.history: Worship from Old Kingdom, remained central throughout Egyptian history

deities.name: Sekhmet
deities.significance: Fierce lioness goddess of war, plague, and healing. Destructive aspect of Ra's power. Healer and destroyer.
deities.impact: Sekhmet worship involved careful propitiation to avoid wrath. Role as healer made her accessible.
deities.alterEgos: Lioness Warrior (predatory form), Plague-Bringer (disease form), Healer (medicinal)
deities.relationships: Father: Ra. Aspect of: Hathor (gentler version).
deities.powers: War mastery, plague generation and curing, heat and fire control, healing magic
deities.temples: Temples at Karnak, Memphis, throughout Egypt
deities.history: Worship from Old Kingdom, remained important throughout history

deities.name: Bastet
deities.significance: Goddess of cats, fertility, and protection. Originally lion/lioness, later associated with domestic cats.
deities.impact: Bastet worship popular and beloved. Killing a cat was capital offense.
deities.alterEgos: Sekhmet (lion warrior form), Gentle Cat (domestic form), Mother Cat (protective)
deities.relationships: Father: Ra. Protective of households and mothers.
deities.powers: Cat communication, fertility granting, household protection, joy and music granting
deities.temples: Major temple at Bubastis, temples throughout Egypt
deities.history: Worship particularly prominent in Late Period

egyptian.overview: Ancient Egyptian religion centered on gods like Ra, Osiris, and Isis. Emphasizes afterlife, mummification, and cosmic order (Ma'at). Reflects civilization's reverence for the Nile and eternal life.

hindu.name: Hindu/Vedic Mythology
hindu.description: One of the world's oldest and most complex mythological systems with hundreds of deities

deities.name: Brahma
deities.significance: Creator god and first of Trimurti (trinity). Created universe and all living beings.
deities.impact: Brahma temples rare compared to other deities. His creation association gave importance.
deities.alterEgos: Self-Born (Svayambhu form), Grandsire (elder aspect), Knowledge-Keeper
deities.relationships: Partner in Trimurti: with Vishnu and Shiva. Daughter: Saraswati.
deities.powers: Universe creation, life creation, Vedas knowledge, deity creation
deities.temples: Brahma Temple in Pushkar (one of few), scattered temples in India
deities.worshipers: Limited direct worship - estimated few million focus on him, billions acknowledge
deities.history: Vedic deity from 1500 BCE, worship declined after classical period

deities.name: Vishnu
deities.significance: Preserver god and maintainer of cosmic order (dharma). Descends in avatars when dharma threatened.
deities.impact: Vishnu worship widespread and beloved. His avatars provide ideal behavior templates.
deities.alterEgos: Narasimha (man-lion form), Kurma (tortoise form), Varaha (boar form), Rama, Krishna
deities.relationships: Wife: Lakshmi. Partner in Trimurti: with Brahma and Shiva.
deities.powers: Universe preservation, avatar incarnation, dharma protection, divine intervention
deities.temples: Temples throughout India, especially at Mathura, Vrindavan, Ayodhya
deities.worshipers: Estimated 800+ million at peak and through history
deities.history: Vedic deity from 1500 BCE, became central to Hinduism

deities.name: Shiva
deities.significance: Destroyer and transformer god. Destruction necessary for renewal. Cosmic dance (Nataraja) symbolizes cycles.
deities.impact: Shiva worship emphasizes yoga, meditation, asceticism. Destruction understood as necessary.
deities.alterEgos: Nataraja (cosmic dancer form), Mahakala (great time/death form), Rudra (fearsome form)
deities.relationships: Wife: Parvati. Children: Ganesha, Skanda. Partner in Trimurti.
deities.powers: Destruction and transformation, cosmic dance power, yoga mastery, third eye power
deities.temples: Temples throughout India especially Varanasi, Rameswaram, Kedarnath
deities.worshipers: Estimated 800+ million at peak and through history
deities.history: Vedic deity from 1500 BCE, became central to Hinduism

deities.name: Ganesha
deities.significance: Elephant-headed god of obstacles and new beginnings. Removes obstacles, invoked at venture start.
deities.impact: Ganesha worship nearly universal in Hinduism. Festivals are joyful celebrations.
deities.alterEgos: Elephant-Headed Remover (obstacle form), Sweet-Toothed Lover (playful)
deities.relationships: Parents: Shiva and Parvati. Brother: Skanda.
deities.powers: Obstacle removal, wisdom granting, auspiciousness granting, elephant communication
deities.temples: Ganesha temples throughout India, household shrines (most common)
deities.worshipers: Estimated 1+ billion at peak, nearly universal in Hindu households
deities.history: Became prominent deity during medieval period

deities.name: Durga
deities.significance: Warrior goddess and manifestation of shakti (divine feminine power). Battles demons.
deities.impact: Durga Puja major festival. Her warrior nature challenged gender norms.
deities.alterEgos: Kali (destroyer form), Lakshmi (prosperity form), Uma (gentle form)
deities.relationships: Manifestation of: Shakti (divine feminine). Mount: Lion.
deities.powers: Warfare mastery, demon-slaying, protection granting, shakti manifestation
deities.temples: Durga temples throughout India
deities.history: Became prominent deity, nearly universal worship

deities.name: Lakshmi
deities.significance: Goddess of wealth, fortune, and prosperity. Consort of Vishnu, invoked for abundance.
deities.impact: Lakshmi worship universal at festivals. Diwali celebrates her return.
deities.alterEgos: Padma (lotus form), Wealth-Bringer (prosperity form)
deities.relationships: Wife/Partner: Vishnu.
deities.powers: Wealth granting, fortune bestowal, prosperity blessing
deities.temples: Lakshmi temples throughout India, household shrines
deities.history: Vedic roots, became prominent in classical period

deities.name: Krishna
deities.significance: Avatar of Vishnu. Eighth incarnation of Vishnu in human form. Central to Bhagavad Gita.
deities.impact: Krishna cults spread throughout Hindu world. Most beloved deity for many Hindus.
deities.alterEgos: Cowherd (pastoral form), Charioteer (Arjuna's guide), Divine Lover (romantic form)
deities.relationships: Avatar of: Vishnu. Lover: Radha (divine feminine aspect). Ally: Arjuna.
deities.powers: Divine knowledge, flute magic, avatar powers, cosmic vision (Virata form)
deities.temples: Temples throughout India especially Mathura, Vrindavan, Dwaraka
deities.worshipers: Estimated 500+ million at peak, most beloved for many
deities.history: Central figure in Bhagavad Gita and Mahabharata

deities.name: Rama
deities.significance: Avatar of Vishnu. Seventh incarnation. Hero of Ramayana. Ideal ruler and person.
deities.impact: Rama cults spread throughout Hindu world. Ramayana among most influential texts.
deities.alterEgos: Prince of Ayodhya (royal form), Bowhunter (warrior form)
deities.relationships: Avatar of: Vishnu. Wife: Sita (abducted by Ravana). Sons: Kusha and Lava.
deities.powers: Dharma power, bow mastery, divine strength, cosmic knowledge
deities.temples: Temples throughout India especially Ayodhya, Varanasi
deities.history: Central figure in Ramayana epic, ideal Hindu model

hindu.overview: Hindu mythology featuring the Trimurti (Brahma, Vishnu, Shiva) and their avatars. Rich with epics like Ramayana and Mahabharata. Explores dharma, karma, and the cycle of creation.

japanese.name: Japanese/Shinto Mythology
japanese.description: Japanese mythology featuring kami (spirits/deities) and the creation of the islands of Japan

deities.name: Izanagi
deities.significance: Creator god who created the islands of Japan with wife Izanami using sacred spear.
deities.impact: Izanagi creation myth fundamental to Japanese identity and Shinto.
deities.alterEgos: The Creator (creation aspect), Primordial Male (gender aspect)
deities.relationships: Wife: Izanami (journeyed to underworld to retrieve her). Children: Islands, major deities.
deities.powers: Island creation, deity creation, life granting
deities.temples: Izanagi Shrine in Hyogo (primary shrine)
deities.history: Foundational to Shinto creation mythology

deities.name: Amaterasu
deities.significance: Goddess of the sun. Most important kami in Shinto. Divine ancestor of Japanese imperial family.
deities.impact: Amaterasu worship central to Japanese identity and imperial legitimacy.
deities.alterEgos: The Hidden Goddess (when retreating into cave)
deities.relationships: Parents: Izanagi and Izanami. Siblings: Tsukuyomi, Susanoo.
deities.powers: Sun control, imperial blessing, divine radiance
deities.temples: Ise Grand Shrine (most sacred Shinto shrine in Japan)
deities.worshipers: Estimated 100+ million, central to Japanese religious identity
deities.history: Central to Shinto and Japanese imperial tradition

deities.name: Susanoo
deities.significance: God of storm, wind, and the sea. Slayed the serpent Yamata no Orochi.
deities.impact: Susanoo worship widespread, particularly for storm protection.
deities.alterEgos: The Storm God (weather form), Serpent Slayer (hero form)
deities.relationships: Parents: Izanagi and Izanami. Sister: Amaterasu. Son: Okuninushi.
deities.powers: Storm summoning, wind control, serpent-slaying, sword mastery
deities.temples: Susanoo shrines throughout Japan, especially Izumo
deities.history: Important kami in Shinto, patron of warriors

deities.name: Inari
deities.significance: Goddess of agriculture, prosperity, and rice. One of most widely worshipped kami in Japan.
deities.impact: Inari worship extremely widespread. Inari shrines most common in Japan.
deities.alterEgos: Fox Deity (kitsune form), Fertility Bringer (agriculture form)
deities.relationships: Associated with: Foxes (kitsune) as messengers.
deities.powers: Crop blessing, prosperity granting, fox communication
deities.temples: Fushimi Inari Shrine (most famous with thousands of torii gates), thousands of shrines nationwide
deities.worshipers: Estimated 100+ million, most widely worshipped kami
deities.history: Originally agricultural deity, became merchant patron

japanese.overview: Japanese mythology featuring kami spirits and primordial deities. Celebrates creation myths, nature spirits, and imperial lineage. Foundation of Shinto tradition.

chinese.name: Chinese Mythology
chinese.description: One of the world's oldest continuous mythologies spanning thousands of years

deities.name: Pangu
deities.significance: Primordial being who created the universe from cosmic egg. His body became the world.
deities.impact: Pangu creation myth foundational to Chinese cosmology.
deities.alterEgos: The Universe Embodied (cosmic form)
deities.relationships: Created: the entire universe and cosmos.
deities.powers: Universe creation, cosmic force
deities.temples: Pangu temples in China, particularly in Guangdong
deities.history: Central to Chinese creation mythology

deities.name: Jade Emperor (Yuhuang Dadi)
deities.significance: Ruler of heaven, earth, and underworld. Most important deity in Chinese popular religion.
deities.impact: Jade Emperor worship central to Chinese religious practice.
deities.alterEgos: Celestial Emperor (cosmic rule form)
deities.relationships: Rules over: Heaven, Earth, Underworld and all beings within them.
deities.powers: Universal rule, life and death authority, cosmic governance
deities.temples: Jade Emperor temples throughout China, especially Beijing
deities.history: Central to Chinese cosmology and religious practice

deities.name: Xi Wangmu (Queen Mother of the West)
deities.significance: Ancient goddess ruling Mount Kunlun. Source of immortality through peaches. Associated with both death and immortality.
deities.impact: Xi Wangmu worship very ancient. Central to Daoist immortality concepts.
deities.alterEgos: Mother of Immortality (immortal aspect), Death Bringer (mortality aspect)
deities.relationships: Rules: Mount Kunlun and western paradise.
deities.powers: Immortality granting, peach magic, Mount Kunlun rule, tiger communication
deities.temples: Xi Wangmu temples throughout China
deities.history: One of oldest Chinese deities, central to immortality beliefs

deities.name: Guanyu
deities.significance: Deified historical general. Symbol of loyalty, righteousness, and martial prowess. Worshipped as a god.
deities.impact: Guanyu worship extremely widespread. One of most popular deities in Chinese culture.
deities.alterEgos: God of War (martial aspect), Righteous Saint (virtue aspect)
deities.relationships: Brother-in-arms: with Liu Bei and Zhang Fei (sworn brothers).
deities.powers: Warfare mastery, righteous judgment, fate guidance
deities.temples: Guanyu temples throughout China, Asia, and Chinese diaspora
deities.worshipers: Estimated 100+ million at peak and through history
deities.history: Historical figure (160-219 CE) deified and worshipped as god

chinese.overview: Chinese mythology blending folk traditions, philosophy, and history. Features jade emperors, immortals, and dragons. Reflects Confucian and Taoist values of harmony and cosmic balance.

mesoamerican.name: Mesoamerican Mythology
mesoamerican.description: Mythology of the Aztec, Maya, and other Mesoamerican civilizations

deities.name: Quetzalcoatl
deities.significance: Feathered serpent god. Creator deity associated with wind, air, and knowledge. Divine mentor to humanity.
deities.impact: Quetzalcoatl worship central to Mesoamerican civilization.
deities.alterEgos: Feathered Serpent (creation form), Wind God (Ehecatl form), The Returning God
deities.relationships: Creator of: humanity and civilization. Allied with: Tezcatlipoca (dual creator).
deities.powers: Wind mastery, knowledge granting, civilization creation, shapeshifting
deities.temples: Temple of Quetzalcoatl at Teotihuacan, temples throughout Mesoamerica
deities.history: Worship from Toltec period through Aztec era

deities.name: Tezcatlipoca
deities.significance: Smoking Mirror god. Associated with night, sorcery, and destiny. Powerful and unpredictable.
deities.impact: Tezcatlipoca worship central to Aztec cosmology.
deities.alterEgos: Smoking Mirror (sorcery form), Jaguar God (animal form), Night Lord (nocturnal form)
deities.relationships: Dual creator with: Quetzalcoatl. Adversarial relationship with multiple deities.
deities.powers: Sorcery mastery, fate control, obsidian magic, jaguar summoning
deities.temples: Temples throughout Mesoamerica, especially Aztec capital
deities.history: Central to Aztec religion and cosmology

deities.name: Huitzilopochtli
deities.significance: Hummingbird of the left god. Aztec patron deity and god of war and the sun.
deities.impact: Huitzilopochtli worship central to Aztec identity. Led Aztecs to build Tenochtitlan.
deities.alterEgos: Hummingbird (swift form), Sun God (solar form), War Leader (military form)
deities.relationships: Mother: Coatlicue. Led the Aztecs: to Tenochtitlan as promised.
deities.powers: War mastery, sun power, swift movement, hummingbird communication
deities.temples: Great Temple (Templo Mayor) in Tenochtitlan
deities.worshipers: Estimated 10+ million at peak among Aztecs
deities.history: Central to Aztec civilization and empire

deities.name: Xibalba Lords (Underworld Deities)
deities.significance: Collective lords ruling Xibalba (Mayan underworld). Associated with death and suffering.
deities.impact: Central to Mayan cosmology and underworld beliefs.
deities.alterEgos: Death Lords (collective manifestation), Disease Bringers (plague aspect)
deities.relationships: Rules: Xibalba and all dead within. Opposed by: Hero Twins (Hunahpu and Xbalanque).
deities.powers: Death authority, underworld rule, disease spreading
deities.temples: Mayan temples throughout Mesoamerica, especially at Chichen Itza
deities.history: Central to Mayan cosmology documented in Popol Vuh

mesoamerican.overview: Aztec and Mayan mythology featuring complex pantheons and cosmologies. Emphasizes human sacrifice, calendar cycles, and deity interactions. Rich astronomical knowledge embedded in myths.

celtic.name: Celtic Mythology
celtic.description: Mythology of the Celtic peoples of Europe, particularly Ireland, Wales, and Brittany

deities.name: The Dagda
deities.significance: All-father figure in Irish mythology. God of magic, fertility, and war. Wielder of magical cauldron.
deities.impact: Dagda worship central to Irish pagan religion.
deities.alterEgos: The Good God (benevolent form), Druid (magical form)
deities.relationships: Children: Brigid, Aengus. Wife: Mór-Ríghan.
deities.powers: Magic mastery, weather control, fertility granting, cauldron summoning
deities.temples: Sacred sites throughout Ireland, especially Tara
deities.history: Central to Irish mythology and pagan beliefs

deities.name: Brigid
deities.significance: Triple goddess of fire, poetry, healing, and smithcraft. One of most important Celtic deities.
deities.impact: Brigid worship extremely widespread. Later merged with St. Brigid in Christianity.
deities.alterEgos: Triple Goddess (three aspects), Healer (medicinal form), Smith (craft form)
deities.relationships: Father: The Dagda. Revered by: poets, smiths, healers.
deities.powers: Fire control, poetry inspiration, healing magic, smithcraft enhancement
deities.temples: Sacred wells throughout Ireland, temples at Kildare
deities.history: One of most important Celtic deities, survived Christianization

deities.name: Lugh
deities.significance: God of light, crafts, and war. Master of many skills. Father of great hero Cu Chulainn.
deities.impact: Lugh worship widespread among Celtic peoples.
deities.alterEgos: The Bright One (light form), Master of All Arts (craft form)
deities.relationships: Father of: Cu Chulainn (greatest Celtic hero).
deities.powers: Light mastery, craft enhancement, war prowess, magic mastery
deities.temples: Temples throughout Celtic lands, festival sites
deities.history: Widely worshipped Celtic deity

celtic.overview: Celtic mythology from Ireland, Wales, and Brittany. Features gods, fairies, and heroes in mystical landscapes. Celebrates cycles of nature, warrior culture, and spiritual wisdom.

mesopotamian.name: Mesopotamian Mythology
mesopotamian.description: Mythology of ancient Sumer, Akkad, Babylon, and Assyria

deities.name: Marduk
deities.significance: Chief god of Babylon. Creator deity in Enuma Elish. Slayer of primordial chaos.
deities.impact: Marduk worship became central to Babylonian civilization.
deities.alterEgos: King of Gods (rulership form), Dragon Slayer (hero form), Destiny Keeper
deities.relationships: Created: the world and humanity. Rules: Babylon and cosmos.
deities.powers: Creation magic, chaos control, kingship granting, destiny determination
deities.temples: Esagila Temple in Babylon (most important Mesopotamian temple)
deities.worshipers: Estimated 10+ million at peak among Babylonians
deities.history: Worship became dominant in Babylonian period

deities.name: Primordial Gods (Tiamat, Apsu, Mummu)
deities.significance: Primordial forces in Enuma Elish creation myth. Tiamat represents chaos overcome.
deities.impact: Central to Mesopotamian creation cosmology.
deities.alterEgos: Primordial Chaos (manifest form), Saltwaters (oceanic form)
deities.relationships: Generate: all younger gods through conflict.
deities.powers: Primordial force, creation power, chaos manifestation
deities.temples: Part of creation mythology, limited direct worship
deities.history: Central to Enuma Elish myth

deities.name: Ishtar
deities.significance: Goddess of love, war, and sexuality. Most important female deity in Mesopotamia.
deities.impact: Ishtar worship widespread and important.
deities.alterEgos: Morning Star (Venus form), War Goddess (military form)
deities.relationships: Husband: Tammuz. Lover of multiple gods.
deities.powers: Love magic, warfare prowess, sexuality power, star control
deities.temples: Ishtar temples throughout Mesopotamia
deities.history: Widely worshipped throughout Mesopotamian history

mesopotamian.overview: Ancient Sumerian and Babylonian mythology with gods like Marduk and Inanna. Features creation myths and divine councils. Foundation of written mythology and cuneiform records.

polynesian.name: Polynesian Mythology
polynesian.description: Mythology of the Hawaiian, Samoan, Maori, Tahitian, and other Pacific Island peoples

deities.name: Maui
deities.significance: Greatest Polynesian cultural hero. Pulled islands from the sea, slowed the sun, discovered fire.
deities.impact: Maui stories central to all Polynesian cultures. Most famous Polynesian figure.
deities.alterEgos: The Trickster (cunning form), Sun-Slayer (heroic form), Island-Fisher (creation aspect)
deities.relationships: Mother: Hina. Rivals with: Sun (Maui slowed its descent). Allies: Polynesian peoples.
deities.powers: Trickery mastery, fire discovery, island pulling, sun manipulation, transformation
deities.temples: Sacred sites throughout Pacific Islands
deities.history: Central to Hawaiian, Maori, Samoan, and Tahitian cultures

deities.name: Pele
deities.significance: Hawaiian volcano goddess. Creator and destroyer. Lives in Kilauea volcano.
deities.impact: Pele worship central to Hawaiian culture and beliefs.
deities.alterEgos: The Fire Goddess (volcanic form), Destroyer (lava aspect), Creator (island-building form)
deities.relationships: Mother: Haumea. Children: Namaka, Kapo. Love interest: Lohi'au.
deities.powers: Fire control, volcano mastery, lava creation, destruction and creation
deities.temples: Crater of Kilauea (primary sacred site), temples throughout Hawaii
deities.history: Central to Hawaiian mythology and volcano worship

deities.name: Tangaroa
deities.significance: Polynesian sea god. Ruler of all oceans and marine life. Creator of fish.
deities.impact: Tangaroa worship important for fishing cultures.
deities.alterEgos: The Ocean God (marine form), Fish Creator (fertility form)
deities.relationships: Created: all fish and sea creatures. Rules: all oceans.
deities.powers: Ocean control, fish creation, storm summoning, tide manipulation
deities.temples: Ocean-side temples throughout Polynesia
deities.worshipers: Estimated 5+ million among Polynesian seafaring peoples
deities.history: Important to seafaring Polynesian cultures

deities.name: Hina
deities.significance: Moon goddess and mother of Maui. Associated with feminine power and crafts.
deities.impact: Hina worship widespread among Polynesian peoples.
deities.alterEgos: The Moon Goddess (lunar form), Mother of Maui (maternal form)
deities.relationships: Son: Maui (great hero). Revered by: women, crafters.
deities.powers: Moon control, craft inspiration, feminine power, fertility granting
deities.temples: Moon shrines throughout Polynesia
deities.history: Important goddess across Polynesian cultures

polynesian.overview: Pacific Islander mythology featuring gods like Maui and Pele. Celebrates ocean voyages, natural forces, and ancestral connections. Rich oral tradition across island cultures.

native_american.name: Native American Mythology
native_american.description: Mythology of various Native American tribes and peoples (Navajo, Cherokee, Lakota, Pacific Northwest, etc.)

deities.name: Coyote
deities.significance: Trickster figure across many Native American cultures. Creator, chaos-bringer, and wise teacher.
deities.impact: Coyote stories central to Native American oral traditions across many tribes.
deities.alterEgos: The Trickster (cunning form), Creator (world-making form), Teacher (wisdom aspect)
deities.relationships: Interacts with: all creatures and peoples. Neither wholly good nor evil.
deities.powers: Trickery mastery, shapeshifting, creation magic, chaos summoning, wisdom granting
deities.temples: Sacred coyote sites throughout North America
deities.worshipers: Estimated 10+ million across many Native American tribes
deities.history: Trickster figure in Southwest, Pacific Northwest, Great Plains cultures

deities.name: Raven
deities.significance: Pacific Northwest creator figure. Brought light to the world. Master trickster.
deities.impact: Raven stories central to Pacific Northwest tribal traditions.
deities.alterEgos: The Light-Bringer (creation form), The Trickster (cunning form), The Transformer
deities.relationships: Created: light, brought transformation to world.
deities.powers: Light creation, shapeshifting, trickery, transformation magic
deities.temples: Sacred raven sites in Pacific Northwest
deities.worshipers: Estimated 5+ million among Pacific Northwest tribes
deities.history: Central to Haida, Tlingit, and other Pacific Northwest cultures

deities.name: Mother Earth / Pachamama
deities.significance: Earth mother goddess revered across Native American cultures. Giver of life and abundance.
deities.impact: Earth Mother worship fundamental to Native American spirituality.
deities.alterEgos: The Nurturer (fertility form), The Provider (abundance form)
deities.relationships: Mother to: all living things. Sustains: all life.
deities.powers: Life creation, fertility granting, abundance provision, earth control
deities.temples: Natural sacred sites throughout Americas
deities.worshipers: Estimated 15+ million across Native American peoples
deities.history: Central to most Native American cultures

deities.name: Thunderbird
deities.significance: Powerful spirit bird controlling thunder and lightning. Symbol of power and dominion.
deities.impact: Thunderbird worship widespread across many tribes.
deities.alterEgos: The Storm Bringer (weather form), The Great Eagle (flight form)
deities.relationships: Controls: storms and weather. Revered by: warriors and hunters.
deities.powers: Thunder summoning, lightning control, storm mastery, divine power
deities.temples: Mountain and sky sacred sites throughout North America
deities.history: Important across many Native American cultures

african.name: African Mythology
african.description: Mythology of various African peoples, particularly West and Central African Yoruba and other groups

deities.name: Oshun
deities.significance: Yoruba goddess of love, beauty, fertility, and rivers. One of most beloved Orisha.
deities.impact: Oshun worship spread throughout African diaspora and Americas.
deities.alterEgos: The River Goddess (water form), The Golden One (beauty form)
deities.relationships: Mother: Yemaya. Lover/Wife: Shango. Revered by: women, lovers.
deities.powers: Love and desire inducement, beauty enhancement, river control, fertility granting
deities.temples: River shrines throughout Africa and Americas
deities.history: Central to Yoruba religion, survived through slavery in Americas

deities.name: Shango
deities.significance: Yoruba god of thunder, lightning, war, and justice. Powerful warrior king deified.
deities.impact: Shango worship spread throughout African diaspora.
deities.alterEgos: The Thunder God (storm form), The Warrior King (military form)
deities.relationships: Parents: Yemaya and Aganju. Wife: Oshun. Warrior: legendary fighter.
deities.powers: Thunder summoning, lightning control, warfare mastery, justice enforcement
deities.temples: Shango shrines throughout Africa and Americas
deities.history: Central to Yoruba religion, deified historical figure

deities.name: Anansi
deities.significance: West African spider trickster. Master of stories and cunning. Survived slavery through folklore.
deities.impact: Anansi stories spread throughout African diaspora and Caribbean.
deities.alterEgos: The Trickster (cunning form), The Storyteller (oral form), The Spider
deities.relationships: Outwits: gods, humans, animals. Revered by: storytellers.
deities.powers: Trickery mastery, web weaving, story magic, cunning intelligence
deities.temples: Oral tradition temples (storytelling circles)
deities.history: Central to many West African cultures, survived through diaspora

deities.name: Yemaya
deities.significance: Yoruba mother goddess and ocean deity. Mother of many Orisha. Protector of children.
deities.impact: Yemaya worship spread throughout African diaspora.
deities.alterEgos: The Ocean Mother (oceanic form), The Great Mother (maternal form)
deities.relationships: Mother to: many Orisha and peoples. Protector: of children and women.
deities.powers: Ocean control, motherhood power, protection granting, fertility blessing
deities.temples: Ocean-side shrines throughout Africa and Americas
deities.history: Central to Yoruba religion, survived through diaspora

slavic.name: Slavic Mythology
slavic.description: Mythology of Slavic peoples of Eastern Europe before Christianization

deities.name: Perun
deities.significance: Slavic sky god and god of thunder. Ruler of sky and weather. Chief Slavic deity.
deities.impact: Perun worship central to Slavic pagan religion.
deities.alterEgos: The Thunder God (storm form), The Sky Father (primordial form)
deities.relationships: Rules: sky and weather. Revered by: warriors.
deities.powers: Thunder summoning, lightning control, weather mastery, war prowess
deities.temples: Oak groves and mountain temples throughout Slavic lands
deities.history: Chief Slavic deity until Christianization (10th-12th centuries)

deities.name: Veles
deities.significance: God of earth, cattle, wealth, and underworld. Fertility and prosperity deity.
deities.impact: Veles worship important to agricultural Slavic societies.
deities.alterEgos: The Earth God (terrestrial form), The Wealth Giver (prosperity form)
deities.relationships: Rules: earth and underworld. Rival: Perun (sky god).
deities.powers: Earth control, cattle blessing, wealth granting, underworld mastery
deities.temples: Earth and forest shrines throughout Slavic lands
deities.history: Important Slavic fertility and prosperity deity

deities.name: Marzanna
deities.significance: Slavic goddess of winter, death, and rebirth. Embodied winter's harshness and renewal.
deities.impact: Marzanna worship tied to seasonal cycles.
deities.alterEgos: The Winter Goddess (cold form), Death Bringer (mortality form)
deities.relationships: Rules: winter season. Cycles: with spring rebirth.
deities.powers: Winter control, death bringing, rebirth granting, seasonal cycle influence
deities.temples: Winter sites and sacred groves
deities.history: Seasonal deity in Slavic mythology

deities.name: Dazhbog
deities.significance: Slavic sun god. Giver of light and wealth. Associated with fortune and prosperity.
deities.impact: Dazhbog worship important to Slavic sun worship.
deities.alterEgos: The Sun God (solar form), The Wealth Giver (prosperity form)
deities.relationships: Rules: sun and light. Giver: of wealth and fortune.
deities.powers: Sun control, light creation, wealth granting, fortune bestowing
deities.temples: Sun temples throughout Slavic lands
deities.history: Important Slavic solar deity

korean.name: Korean Mythology
korean.description: Mythology of the Korean peninsula including shamanism and early kingdom legends

deities.name: Hwanung
deities.significance: Divine being who descended to earth to establish civilization. Father of Korean people.
deities.impact: Hwanung legend foundational to Korean cultural identity.
deities.alterEgos: The Heavenly Prince (divine form), Civilization Bringer (cultural form)
deities.relationships: Father: Hananim. Son: Dangun (founder of first Korean kingdom).
deities.powers: Civilization creation, cultural establishment, divine blessing
deities.temples: Shrine of Hwanung throughout Korea
deities.history: Foundational to Korean mythology and identity

deities.name: Dangun Wanggeom
deities.significance: Legendary founder of Gojoseon, first Korean kingdom. Son of Hwanung.
deities.impact: Dangun worship central to Korean national and cultural identity.
deities.alterEgos: The Founder (founding form), King (royal form)
deities.relationships: Father: Hwanung. Founded: Gojoseon (first Korean kingdom).
deities.powers: Kingdom creation, nation founding, royal blessing
deities.temples: Tangun temples and shrines throughout Korea
deities.history: Central to Korean national mythology

germanic.name: Germanic Mythology
germanic.description: Mythology of Germanic peoples (distinct from Norse, though related)

deities.name: Donar
deities.significance: Germanic god of thunder and protection. Similar to Norse Thor.
deities.impact: Donar worship widespread among Germanic peoples.
deities.alterEgos: The Thunder God (storm form), Oak God (tree form)
deities.relationships: Revered by: warriors and farmers.
deities.powers: Thunder summoning, lightning control, oak mastery, protection granting
deities.temples: Oak groves and mountain sites throughout Germanic lands
deities.history: Central to Germanic pagan religion

deities.name: Wodan
deities.significance: Germanic god of war, wisdom, and magic. Similar to Norse Odin.
deities.impact: Wodan worship important to Germanic religion.
deities.alterEgos: The All-Father (primordial form), The Wise One (wisdom form)
deities.relationships: Rules: war and wisdom. Mentor: to warriors.
deities.powers: War mastery, wisdom granting, magic power, death authority
deities.temples: Sacred groves throughout Germanic lands
deities.history: Central to Germanic pagan religion

deities.name: Frija
deities.significance: Germanic goddess of marriage, motherhood, and home. Similar to Norse Frigg.
deities.impact: Frija worship important to Germanic household religion.
deities.alterEgos: The Beloved (marital form), Mother (maternal form)
deities.relationships: Husband: Wodan. Revered by: women and families.
deities.powers: Marriage blessing, motherhood power, home protection
deities.temples: Household shrines and sacred groves
deities.history: Important to Germanic household religion

persian.name: Persian/Zoroastrian Mythology
persian.description: Ancient Persian mythology and Zoroastrian religious figures

deities.name: Ahura Mazda
deities.significance: Supreme god of Zoroastrianism. Creator of all good things. Embodies wisdom and light.
deities.impact: Ahura Mazda worship central to Zoroastrian faith, one of world's oldest monotheistic religions.
deities.alterEgos: The Wise Lord (wisdom form), Creator (creative form), Light Bringer
deities.relationships: Creator of: Amesha Spentas (divine attributes). Opponent of: Ahriman (evil).
deities.powers: Creation mastery, wisdom granting, light control, good manifestation
deities.temples: Fire temples throughout Persia and Zoroastrian communities
deities.worshipers: Estimated 5+ million at peak, millions remain today
deities.history: Central to Zoroastrianism (700 BCE to modern era)

deities.name: Ahriman
deities.significance: Spirit of evil and destruction in Zoroastrianism. Opposes Ahura Mazda.
deities.impact: Ahriman concept influenced dualistic religions and Western concepts of Satan.
deities.alterEgos: The Destructive Spirit (destructive form), Darkness Embodied
deities.relationships: Opposes: Ahura Mazda. Spreads: evil, disease, death.
deities.powers: Evil manifestation, darkness control, destruction spreading, corruption
deities.temples: No temples (opposition figure)
deities.worshipers: Not worshipped, only opposed and resisted
deities.history: Central opposing force in Zoroastrian cosmology

deities.name: Mithra
deities.significance: God of contracts, oaths, and the sun. Guardian of justice and loyalty.
deities.impact: Mithra worship spread throughout Persian Empire and Mediterranean.
deities.alterEgos: The Sun God (solar form), The Just Judge (judicial form)
deities.relationships: Enforces: contracts and oaths. Associated with: Ahura Mazda.
deities.powers: Contract enforcement, oath power, sun control, justice granting
deities.temples: Mithraic temples throughout Persian Empire and Roman territories
deities.history: Worship spread to Roman Empire, influenced Christianity

sumerian.name: Sumerian Mythology
sumerian.description: Mythology of ancient Sumer, one of humanity's oldest civilizations

deities.name: Anu
deities.significance: Sumerian sky god. Primordial force and father of gods.
deities.impact: Anu worship foundational to Sumerian civilization.
deities.alterEgos: The Sky Father (paternal form), Heaven Embodied
deities.relationships: Father to: many gods. Rules: the heavens.
deities.powers: Sky mastery, heaven rule, cosmic force
deities.temples: Sky temples throughout Sumer
deities.history: Central to Sumerian cosmology

deities.name: Enlil
deities.significance: God of wind, air, and storm. Chief god of Nippur. Wielder of authority.
deities.impact: Enlil worship central to Sumerian religion.
deities.alterEgos: The Storm God (weather form), Authority Bringer (command form)
deities.relationships: Father: Anu. Children: Ninurta and others. Wielder of: authority.
deities.powers: Wind control, storm summoning, authority granting, cosmic order maintenance
deities.temples: Great temple at Nippur
deities.history: Chief deity of Nippur and Sumerian civilization

deities.name: Enki
deities.significance: God of fresh water, wisdom, and magic. Creator of humans.
deities.impact: Enki worship important to Sumerian civilization.
deities.alterEgos: The Wise One (wisdom form), Water Master (aquatic form)
deities.relationships: Father: Anu. Children: Marduk and others. Partner: Ninhursag.
deities.powers: Water control, wisdom granting, magic mastery, human creation
deities.temples: Temple at Eridu (oldest Sumerian temple)
deities.history: Central to Sumerian creation and civilization myths

inca.name: Incan Mythology
inca.description: Mythology of the Incan Empire of South America

deities.name: Inti
deities.significance: Incan sun god. Divine ancestor of Incan royal family.
deities.impact: Inti worship central to Incan civilization and identity.
deities.alterEgos: The Sun God (solar form), Divine Ancestor (royal form)
deities.relationships: Children: Manco Capac and Mama Ocllo (founders of Cusco). Divine ancestor of: Incan emperors.
deities.powers: Sun control, light creation, royal blessing, prosperity granting
deities.temples: Temple of the Sun in Cusco (Coricancha)
deities.history: Central to Incan civilization and empire

deities.name: Mama Quilla
deities.significance: Incan moon goddess. Protective of women and fertility.
deities.impact: Mama Quilla worship important to Incan women.
deities.alterEgos: The Moon Goddess (lunar form), Fertility Bringer (fertility form)
deities.relationships: Husband: Inti. Protector: of women and children.
deities.powers: Moon control, fertility granting, protection of women, time influence
deities.temples: Moon temples throughout Incan Empire
deities.history: Important to Incan women and fertility beliefs

deities.name: Viracocha
deities.significance: Supreme creator god in Incan mythology. Created the world and civilization.
deities.impact: Viracocha worship foundational to pre-Incan civilizations.
deities.alterEgos: The Creator (creation form), Civilization Bringer (cultural form)
deities.relationships: Creator of: all existence and civilization.
deities.powers: Creation mastery, civilization establishment, universe control
deities.temples: Temples throughout Incan Empire, especially at Lake Titicaca
deities.worshipers: Estimated 5+ million through pre-Incan and Incan periods
deities.history: Supreme creator deity in Incan cosmology

mayan.name: Mayan Mythology
mayan.description: Mythology of the Maya civilization of Mesoamerica

deities.name: Hunab Ku
deities.significance: Supreme Mayan creator god. Source of all life and cosmic order.
deities.impact: Hunab Ku concept central to Mayan cosmology.
deities.alterEgos: The Creator (creation form), Cosmic Force (universal form)
deities.relationships: Creator of: all gods and existence.
deities.powers: Creation mastery, cosmic order establishment, universe control
deities.temples: Sacred temples throughout Mayan lands
deities.history: Supreme creator in Mayan cosmology

deities.name: Kukulkan
deities.significance: Feathered serpent god. Associated with wind and rain. Bringer of civilization.
deities.impact: Kukulkan worship widespread among Maya. Equated with Quetzalcoatl.
deities.alterEgos: Feathered Serpent (creation form), Wind God (weather form)
deities.relationships: Creator of: civilization and knowledge.
deities.powers: Wind control, rain summoning, feathered serpent manifestation, civilization granting
deities.temples: Temple of Kukulkan at Chichen Itza (iconic pyramid)
deities.history: Central to Mayan religion and pyramid worship

deities.name: Hero Twins (Hunahpu and Xbalanque)
deities.significance: Twin heroes of Popol Vuh. Defeated Xibalba Lords. Creators of humans.
deities.impact: Hero Twin myth central to Mayan cosmology and creation.
deities.alterEgos: Ball Players (sports form), Underworld Heroes (adventurer form)
deities.relationships: Father: Hun Hunahpu. Defeated: Xibalba Lords. Created: humans.
deities.powers: Heroic prowess, underworld navigation, ball game mastery, creation power
deities.temples: Ball courts throughout Mayan lands
deities.history: Central figures in Popol Vuh creation myth

christianity.name: Christianity
christianity.description: Monotheistic religion based on life and teachings of Jesus Christ, centered on the Trinity

holyFigures.name: Jesus Christ
holyFigures.significance: Central figure of Christianity. Believed to be God incarnate. Crucified and resurrected for humanity's salvation. Founder and focus of Christian faith.
holyFigures.history: Born ~4 BCE in Bethlehem, crucified ~30 CE in Jerusalem, resurrection celebrated at Easter
key_teachings: The Kingdom of God is at hand
holyFigures.impact: Founded Christianity, most influential figure in Western civilization

holyFigures.name: God (The Father)
holyFigures.significance: Supreme being and creator of all existence. Part of the Trinity. Omnipotent, omniscient, and eternal. Represents authority, judgment, and unconditional love.
holyFigures.history: Eternal being transcending time and space

holyFigures.name: The Holy Spirit
holyFigures.significance: Third person of the Trinity. Divine presence indwelling believers. Provides spiritual guidance, comfort, and empowerment. Active in salvation and sanctification.
holyFigures.domain: Divine Presence, Spiritual Empowerment, Guidance, Comfort
holyFigures.history: Eternal, sent by God after Jesus ascension

holyFigures.name: Mary (Mother of Jesus)
holyFigures.significance: Mother of Jesus Christ. Perpetual virgin (Catholic/Orthodox). Venerated as intercessor. Model of faith and obedience. Immaculately conceived (Catholic doctrine).
holyFigures.history: Born ~20 BCE, virgin birth of Jesus ~4 BCE, bodily assumption (Catholic/Orthodox)

christianity.holyText: The Bible (Old Testament and New Testament), Church Traditions
christianity.centralBeliefs: Salvation through Jesus Christ, Resurrection, Trinity (Father, Son, Holy Spirit), Eternal life, Divine grace, Redemption through faith
christianity.practices: Prayer, Bible reading, Church attendance, Sacraments, Worship services, Confession, Fasting, Pilgrimage

denominations.name: Catholicism
denominations.characteristics: Papal authority, Mary veneration, sacraments, apostolic succession

denominations.name: Protestantism
denominations.characteristics: Sola scriptura (scripture alone), faith alone, priest of all believers

denominations.name: Eastern Orthodox
denominations.characteristics: Icon veneration, liturgical tradition, apostolic succession
denominations.practices: Divine Liturgy, veneration of icons, fasting

denominations.name: Baptist
denominations.characteristics: Adult baptism, congregational autonomy, individual conscience

denominations.name: Pentecostal
denominations.characteristics: Holy Spirit baptism, speaking in tongues, divine healing

denominations.name: Methodist
denominations.characteristics: Methodical approach to holiness, social justice

christianity.overview: Monotheistic faith centered on Jesus Christ as the Son of God and Savior. Emphasizes salvation through faith, grace, redemption, and the Trinity (Father, Son, Holy Spirit). World's largest religion with billions of followers.

branches.name: Western Christianity
branches.description: Includes Catholic and Protestant traditions that developed in Western Europe and the Americas

branches.name: Eastern Christianity
branches.description: Includes Orthodox and Eastern Catholic churches with distinct theology and practices

branches.name: Pentecostal/Charismatic
branches.description: Modern movements emphasizing Holy Spirit baptism, speaking in tongues, and divine healing

islam.name: Islam
islam.description: Monotheistic religion based on teachings of Prophet Muhammad revealed through the Quran

holyFigures.name: Allah
holyFigures.significance: The one God of Islam. Creator of universe and all existence. Omnipotent, omniscient, and merciful. Transcendent yet close to believers. Central to all Islamic faith and practice.
holyFigures.domain: Creation, Divine Unity, Justice, Mercy, Guidance
holyFigures.history: Eternal being revealed throughout Islamic history

holyFigures.name: Prophet Muhammad
holyFigures.role: Final Prophet, Seal of the Prophets
holyFigures.significance: Final and greatest prophet of Islam. Received the Quran from Allah. Model of perfect human behavior (Sunnah). Founded Islamic state and community. Established principles of Islamic law.
holyFigures.domain: Prophecy, Divine Revelation, Spiritual Leadership, Justice
holyFigures.history: Born 570 CE in Mecca, received first revelation 610 CE, died 632 CE

holyFigures.name: Abraham (Ibrahim)
holyFigures.significance: Patriarch and father of monotheism in Islam. Tested by Allah with ultimate trial. Built the Kaaba with Ishmael. Model of faith and obedience. Called 'Friend of Allah'.
holyFigures.history: Ancient patriarch recognized as forefather of Arab peoples through Ishmael

holySites: Jerusalem (Al-Aqsa Mosque, Dome of the Rock)
islam.centralBeliefs: Monotheism (Tawhid), Five Pillars, Muhammad as final prophet, Resurrection, Judgment Day, Divine predestination
islam.practices: Prayer (5 times daily), Fasting (Ramadan), Pilgrimage (Hajj), Charity (Zakat), Testimony of faith (Shahada)

denominations.name: Sunni
denominations.characteristics: Majority tradition, acceptance of first four caliphs, Sharia law

denominations.name: Shia
denominations.characteristics: Imam leadership, hidden Imam concept, esoteric interpretation

denominations.name: Sufi
denominations.characteristics: Mystical spirituality, spiritual orders (tariqahs), ecstatic states

islam.overview: Monotheistic faith founded by Prophet Muhammad, emphasizing submission to Allah (God). Core practices include Five Pillars, Qur'an study, and Shariah law. Emphasizes justice, charity, and community.

branches.name: Sunni Islam
branches.description: The majority branch following the Sunnah (practices of Prophet Muhammad) and caliphate tradition

branches.name: Shia Islam
branches.description: Branch emphasizing Imam leadership, hidden Imam theology, and distinct ritual practices

branches.name: Sufi Islam
branches.description: Mystical branch emphasizing direct spiritual experience and ecstatic union with Allah

hinduism.name: Hinduism
hinduism.description: Diverse religious and philosophical tradition with polytheistic theology and rich mythology

holyFigures.name: Brahman
holyFigures.significance: The absolute, eternal, infinite spiritual force underlying all existence. Not a personal god but ultimate reality. Source of all creation and consciousness. Goal of Hindu spiritual practice is union with Brahman (Moksha).
holyFigures.history: Eternal and transcendent, beyond time and space

holyFigures.name: Trimurti (Brahma, Vishnu, Shiva)
holyFigures.role: Trinity of Gods - Creator, Preserver, Destroyer
holyFigures.significance: Manifestation of Brahman in three forms. Brahma creates, Vishnu preserves, Shiva destroys and transforms. Each represents cosmic functions. Eternal divine cycle.
holyFigures.history: Eternal divine manifestation

holyFigures.name: Krishna
holyFigures.role: Avatar of Vishnu, Divine Teacher, Beloved
holyFigures.significance: Eighth avatar of Vishnu. Central figure in Bhagavad Gita. Teacher of dharma and yoga. Symbol of divine love and compassion. Exemplar of divine play and perfect devotion.
holyFigures.domain: Divine Love, Dharma, Spiritual Wisdom, Joy
holyFigures.history: Avatar of Vishnu in Dvapara Yuga era of Hindu cosmology
holyFigures.lifespan: Mythological (estimated 1200 BCE or earlier in tradition)
holyFigures.impact: Eighth avatar of Vishnu, central to Hindu devotional practice

holyFigures.name: Rama
holyFigures.role: Avatar of Vishnu, Ideal King, Symbol of Dharma
holyFigures.significance: Seventh avatar of Vishnu. Hero of Ramayana. Symbol of ideal kingship, duty, and righteousness. Exemplar of perfect son, brother, husband, and king. Defeated demon Ravana.
holyFigures.history: Avatar of Vishnu in Treta Yuga

hinduism.holyText: Vedas, Upanishads, Bhagavad Gita, Mahabharata, Ramayana, Puranas
hinduism.centralBeliefs: Dharma (duty), Karma (action/consequence), Samsara (rebirth), Moksha (liberation), Brahman (ultimate reality)
hinduism.practices: Puja (worship), Meditation, Yoga, Pilgrimage, Mantra recitation, Scripture study, Festival celebration

denominations.name: Shaktism
denominations.characteristics: Worship of divine feminine (Shakti), Devi worship

hinduism.overview: Ancient polytheistic faith with billions of followers. Emphasizes dharma (duty), karma, and reincarnation. Celebrates diverse deities, yoga, meditation, and the pursuit of moksha (liberation).

branches.name: Vaishnavism
branches.description: Devotion to Vishnu and Krishna, emphasis on Bhakti (devotional love)

branches.name: Shaivism
branches.description: Worship of Shiva, emphasis on meditation, yoga, and transcendence

branches.name: Shaktism
branches.description: Worship of Shakti (divine feminine), goddess-centered spirituality

buddhism.name: Buddhism
buddhism.description: Spiritual tradition based on teachings of Siddhartha Gautama (the Buddha) about suffering and enlightenment

holyFigures.name: Siddhartha Gautama (The Buddha)
holyFigures.significance: Founder of Buddhism. Achieved enlightenment and taught the path to liberation from suffering (Nirvana). Rejected extreme asceticism and indulgence. Perfect example of human potential for awakening.
holyFigures.history: Born ~563 BCE as Prince Siddhartha, achieved enlightenment ~528 BCE, taught 45 years, died ~483 BCE

holyFigures.name: Bodhisattvas
holyFigures.significance: Beings achieving enlightenment but postponing final liberation to help others. Models of compassion and wisdom. Include Avalokiteshvara (compassion) and Manjushri (wisdom).
holyFigures.history: Eternal figures in Buddhist cosmology

buddhism.holyText: Tripitaka, Mahayana Sutras, Tibetan Buddhist texts
buddhism.centralBeliefs: Four Noble Truths, Eightfold Path, Nirvana (liberation), No eternal soul, Impermanence, Karma
buddhism.practices: Meditation, Mindfulness, Dharma study, Monastic discipline, Ethical conduct

denominations.name: Theravada
denominations.characteristics: Oldest surviving school, individual enlightenment, monastic focus

denominations.name: Mahayana
denominations.characteristics: Bodhisattva path, multiple buddhas, lay practice

denominations.name: Vajrayana
denominations.characteristics: Tantric practices, lama guidance, rapid enlightenment

buddhism.overview: Spiritual tradition centered on Buddha's teachings on suffering, enlightenment, and the Middle Way. Emphasizes mindfulness, meditation, and the Noble Eightfold Path. Non-theistic approach to spirituality.

branches.name: Theravada Buddhism
branches.description: The original school emphasizing individual enlightenment and monastic traditions

branches.name: Mahayana Buddhism
branches.description: The bodhisattva path where enlightenment benefits all beings

branches.name: Vajrayana Buddhism
branches.description: Tantric Buddhism emphasizing transformation and rapid enlightenment

judaism.name: Judaism
judaism.description: Ancient monotheistic religion and cultural tradition of the Jewish people with Torah-based practices

holyFigures.name: God (YHWH/Yahweh/Adonai)
holyFigures.significance: The one God of Judaism. Creator of universe. Established covenants with Abraham and Moses. Central to Jewish identity and spiritual practice throughout history.
holyFigures.history: Eternal being revealed through Torah and prophets

holyFigures.name: Abraham
holyFigures.significance: Founder of Judaism covenant with God. Father of Jewish people. Model of faith and obedience. Willing to sacrifice son Isaac. Established monotheism.
holyFigures.history: Ancient patriarch, lived c. 2000 BCE

holyFigures.name: Moses
holyFigures.significance: Received Torah from God on Mount Sinai. Led Jewish people from Egyptian slavery. Greatest prophet in Judaism. Established Jewish law and religious practice.
holyFigures.domain: Divine Law, Liberation, Prophecy, Spiritual Leadership
holyFigures.history: Born c. 1400 BCE, received Torah c. 1300 BCE, led exodus from Egypt

judaism.centralBeliefs: Monotheism, Torah as divine law, Covenant with God, Redemption and Messianic hope, Tikkun Olam (repairing world)
judaism.practices: Torah study, Prayer, Observance of Commandments, Sabbath (Shabbat), Festivals, Dietary laws (Kosher)
