judaism.overview: Ancient monotheistic faith with Torah as foundation. Emphasizes covenant with God, ethical living, and community. Rich tradition of interpretation, prayer, and observance of mitzvot (commandments).

branches.name: Orthodox Judaism
branches.description: Strict observance of Torah and Talmudic law with traditional practices

branches.name: Conservative Judaism
branches.description: Balance between tradition and modern interpretation of Jewish law

branches.name: Reform Judaism
branches.description: Modern adaptation emphasizing universal Jewish principles over strict observance

zoroastrianism.name: Zoroastrianism
zoroastrianism.description: Ancient Persian monotheistic religion, one of humanity's oldest organized faiths

holyFigures.name: Ahura Mazda
holyFigures.significance: Supreme god and creator of all good. Wise, just, and merciful. Represents light, goodness, and order. Eternal struggle against evil (Ahriman).
holyFigures.history: Eternal deity revealed to Zoroaster

holyFigures.name: Zoroaster (Zarathustra)
holyFigures.significance: Founder of Zoroastrianism. Received divine revelation from Ahura Mazda. Taught monotheism and cosmic dualism. One of humanity's first organized religions.
holyFigures.history: Lived c. 1500-600 BCE (date uncertain)

holySites: Fire temples in Iran and worldwide
zoroastrianism.centralBeliefs: Monotheism, Dualism (good vs evil), Free will, Judgment after death, Resurrection, Final victory of good
zoroastrianism.practices: Fire worship, Prayer, Purity (ritual and moral), Charity, Good thoughts, words, and deeds
zoroastrianism.overview: Ancient Persian monotheistic faith emphasizing cosmic struggle between good (Ahura Mazda) and evil (Angra Mainyu). Influential on later religions, emphasizing free will and moral choice.

branches.name: Parsi Zoroastrianism
branches.description: Zoroastrian tradition preserved by Parsi communities in India

branches.name: Iranian Zoroastrianism
branches.description: Zoroastrian traditions continued in Iran with local adaptations

sikhism.name: Sikhism
sikhism.description: Monotheistic religion founded in Punjab combining Hindu and Islamic influences with emphasis on equality

holyFigures.name: Ik Onkar (The One)
holyFigures.significance: One eternal God. Creator of all existence. Transcendent and immanent. Central concept in Sikhism - belief in one unified divine reality. Beyond gender, form, and attributes.
holyFigures.history: Eternal being

holyFigures.name: Guru Nanak
holyFigures.significance: Founder of Sikhism. First of ten human Gurus. Preached monotheism, equality, and social justice. Rejected caste system. Established langar (community kitchen).
holyFigures.domain: Spiritual Leadership, Equality, Social Justice, Divine Truth
holyFigures.history: Born 1469 CE in Punjab, died 1539 CE

sikhism.holyText: Guru Granth Sahib, Writings of the Gurus
sikhism.centralBeliefs: One God, Equality of all, Karma and rebirth, Salvation through grace, Community service (Seva)
sikhism.practices: Prayer, Meditation, Community service, Langar, Khalsa initiation, Religious symbols
sikhism.overview: Indian faith emphasizing one God (Ik Onkar), equality of all humans, and spiritual practice. Celebrates Guru Nanak's teachings, communal service (seva), and distinctive turbans and uncut hair.

branches.name: Khalsa
branches.description: Initiated Sikhs following strict codes of conduct and appearance

branches.name: Sahajdhari
branches.description: Sikhs who practice core beliefs without initiating into the Khalsa

taoism.name: Taoism/Daoism
taoism.description: Chinese philosophical and spiritual tradition based on harmony with the Tao

holyFigures.name: The Tao
holyFigures.significance: The way, path, ultimate principle underlying all existence. Beyond description or form. Source of all phenomena. Harmonizing with Tao leads to peace and enlightenment.
holyFigures.domain: Ultimate Reality, Natural Harmony, Cosmic Order
holyFigures.history: Eternal and transcendent

holyFigures.name: Laozi
holyFigures.significance: Attributed author of Tao Te Ching. Founder of philosophical Taoism. Emphasized living in harmony with nature and simplicity. Deified in religious Taoism.
holyFigures.history: Lived c. 6th century BCE

taoism.holyText: Tao Te Ching, Zhuangzi, Taoist Canons, Internal Alchemy texts
taoism.centralBeliefs: Harmony with Tao, Wu Wei (non-action), Yin-Yang balance, Qi cultivation, Immortality, Return to simplicity
taoism.practices: Meditation, Tai Chi, Qigong, Feng Shui, Alchemy, Rituals, Scripture study
taoism.overview: Chinese philosophical tradition emphasizing Tao (the Way) and living in harmony with nature. Blends philosophy, spirituality, and folk practices. Values simplicity, spontaneity, and balance.

branches.name: Philosophical Taoism
branches.description: Emphasis on Taoist philosophy, natural living, and harmony with the Tao

branches.name: Religious Taoism
branches.description: Worship of Taoist deities, rituals, and organized priesthood

shintoism.name: Shintoism
shintoism.description: Indigenous religion of Japan based on worship of nature spirits (kami) and reverence for ancestors

holyFigures.name: Kami
holyFigures.significance: Infinite divine spirits inhabiting natural phenomena - mountains, rivers, trees. Ancestors become kami. Represent sacred aspects of nature. Possess supernatural powers.
holyFigures.domain: Nature Spirits, Sacred Essence, Natural Forces
holyFigures.history: Eternal and omnipresent in nature

holyFigures.name: Amaterasu Omikami
holyFigures.role: Sun Goddess, Divine Ancestor of Emperor
holyFigures.significance: Supreme kami in Shinto. Sun goddess. Divine ancestor of Japanese imperial family. Holiest kami. Central to Japanese identity and imperial authority.
holyFigures.domain: Sun, Light, Imperial Authority, Divine Ancestry
holyFigures.history: Eternal primordial kami from Japanese creation myth

shintoism.centralBeliefs: Kami veneration, Purity and purification, Harmony with nature, Emperor veneration, Ancestor respect
shintoism.practices: Shrine visits, Purification rituals, Festival participation, Torii gates, Protective amulets
shintoism.overview: Japanese indigenous religion emphasizing reverence for kami (spirits) in nature. Celebrates seasonal festivals, purification rituals, and harmony with the natural world.

bahai.name: Bahai Faith
bahai.description: Monotheistic religion emphasizing unity of humanity and all religions, world peace, and spiritual principles

holyFigures.name: Bahaullah
holyFigures.significance: Latest manifestation of God for this age. Founder of Bahai Faith. Proclaimed establishment of Kingdom of God on earth. Emphasized unity of humanity and world peace.
holyFigures.domain: Divine Manifestation, Unity, World Peace, Spiritual Leadership
holyFigures.history: Born 1817 CE, proclaimed prophethood 1863 CE, died 1892 CE

holyFigures.name: The Bab
holyFigures.significance: Forerunner of Bahaullah. Founder of Babi religion. Proclaimed coming of 'He whom God shall make manifest'. Martyred for faith. Represents preparatory revelation.
holyFigures.history: Born 1819 CE, proclaimed prophethood 1844 CE, executed 1850 CE

bahai.holyText: Writings of Bahaullah, Writings of The Bab, Writings of Abdu'l-Baha
bahai.centralBeliefs: Unity of God, Unity of religions, Unity of humanity, Progressive revelation, World peace, Equality of men and women
bahai.practices: Prayer and meditation, Fasting, Community service, Teaching faith, Scripture study, Holy day celebration

nihilism.name: Nihilism
nihilism.description: Philosophical belief that life has no inherent meaning, purpose, or objective moral values

figures.name: Friedrich Nietzsche
figures.significance: German philosopher who extensively analyzed nihilism and critiqued it. Proposed 'will to power' as alternative. Advocated creating one's own meaning rather than accepting nihilistic despair.
figures.history: Lived 1844-1900 CE, wrote extensively on nihilism and philosophy

figures.name: Ivan Turgenev
figures.significance: Russian novelist who coined the term 'nihilism' in his 1862 novel 'Fathers and Sons'. Popularized concept through literature and cultural debate.

nihilism.critiques: Criticized for leading to despair, depression, destructive behavior, and lack of motivation for moral action
nihilism.followers: Estimated 5-10 million adherents worldwide (academic and cultural)
nihilism.response: Creates opportunity for individual meaning-making and authentic freedom
nihilism.overview: Philosophical position rejecting objective meaning, values, and truth. Emphasizes absurdity of existence and rejection of societal conventions. Questions foundations of knowledge and morality.

existentialism.name: Existentialism
existentialism.description: Philosophical movement emphasizing individual existence, freedom, choice, and responsibility to create meaning

figures.name: Jean-Paul Sartre
figures.significance: French philosopher who formalized existentialism. Argued 'existence precedes essence' - humans have no predefined nature, must create themselves through choices. Emphasized radical freedom and responsibility.
figures.legacy: Shaped 20th century philosophy, political activism, intellectual culture
famous_quotes: Man is condemned to be free

figures.name: Simone de Beauvoir
figures.significance: French existentialist philosopher and writer. Applied existentialism to feminist philosophy. Argued for women's freedom and authentic existence. Explored ethics and human relationships.
figures.legacy: Founded modern feminism, existential ethics
famous_quotes: One is not born, but rather becomes, a woman

figures.name: Albert Camus
figures.significance: French-Algerian philosopher and writer. Explored 'absurdism' - conflict between human search for meaning and universe's silence. Famous for 'The Stranger' and 'The Myth of Sisyphus'.
figures.legacy: Questioned meaning in modern life, ethical philosophy
famous_quotes: There is one way to happiness and that is to cease worrying

existentialism.critiques: Accused of promoting extreme individualism, ignoring social context, leading to relativism
existentialism.followers: Estimated 10-20 million adherents worldwide (academic and cultural)
existentialism.response: Humans are radically free and responsible for creating their own meaning through authentic choices
existentialism.overview: Philosophy emphasizing individual freedom, responsibility, and authenticity. Focuses on existence preceding essence and the anxiety of freedom. Celebrates personal choice and self-creation.

branches.name: Atheistic Existentialism
branches.description: Existentialism without God (Sartre), emphasizing radical freedom and responsibility

branches.name: Theistic Existentialism
branches.description: Existentialism with God (Kierkegaard), emphasizing faith and divine mystery

stoicism.name: Stoicism
stoicism.description: Ancient Greek and Roman philosophical school emphasizing virtue, acceptance of fate, and living in harmony with reason

figures.name: Zeno of Citium
figures.significance: Greek philosopher who founded Stoic school c. 300 BCE. Taught that virtue is the highest good and that living in accordance with reason/nature leads to happiness and tranquility.

figures.name: Marcus Aurelius
figures.significance: Roman Emperor and Stoic philosopher. Wrote 'Meditations' - personal reflections on Stoic philosophy. Exemplified Stoic virtue through life and leadership. Famous for accepting duty and natural order.
figures.legacy: Most famous Stoic philosopher, influential self-help wisdom
famous_quotes: You have power over your mind not outside events

figures.name: Epictetus
figures.significance: Greek Stoic philosopher who was born enslaved. Taught that freedom comes from accepting what we cannot control and exercising virtue in what we can control. Influenced later Stoic thought.
figures.legacy: Influenced Marcus Aurelius, modern Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
famous_quotes: It is impossible for a man to be free when he is a slave to his body

coreConcepts: Accept what you cannot control (amor fati)
Focus on what is within your control
stoicism.critiques: Accused of promoting emotional suppression, fatalism, and passivity in face of injustice
stoicism.followers: Estimated 5 million practicing modern Stoics, widespread in leadership and psychology
stoicism.response: Freedom and peace come through virtue and accepting what is beyond our control
stoicism.overview: Ancient philosophy emphasizing virtue as the highest good and living in accordance with reason. Teaches acceptance of fate, emotional detachment, and inner peace through virtue.

branches.name: Early Stoicism
branches.description: Zeno and early founders emphasizing logic and physics alongside ethics

branches.name: Roman Stoicism
branches.description: Later development through Marcus Aurelius and Epictetus focused on practical virtue

buddhism_philosophy.name: Buddhism (Philosophical)
buddhism_philosophy.description: Philosophical worldview emphasizing suffering, impermanence, no-self, and path to liberation through understanding

figures.name: Siddhartha Gautama (The Buddha)
figures.significance: Founder of Buddhist philosophy. Achieved enlightenment and taught the Four Noble Truths and Eightfold Path as framework for understanding suffering and liberation.
figures.history: Born ~563 BCE, achieved enlightenment ~528 BCE, died ~483 BCE

coreConcepts: Four Noble Truths (suffering, cause, cessation, path)
buddhism_philosophy.critiques: Some view as pessimistic (focus on suffering), others criticize as escapist
buddhism_philosophy.followers: 500+ million Buddhists, millions more study philosophy
buddhism_philosophy.response: Understanding the nature of suffering and impermanence leads to liberation and peace

materialism.name: Materialism (Philosophical)
materialism.description: Worldview asserting that only matter/physical substance is real; consciousness and mind arise from physical processes

figures.name: Democritus
figures.significance: Ancient Greek philosopher who argued that only atoms and void exist. Everything, including mind and consciousness, results from physical atomic interactions. Pioneer of mechanistic worldview.

figures.name: Karl Marx
figures.significance: German philosopher who developed 'historical materialism' - analysis of history through material economic conditions. Argued economic systems determine social structures, ideology, and consciousness.

figures.name: Ludwig Feuerbach
figures.significance: German philosopher who argued that religion and ideology are human projections of material conditions. Influenced Marx's materialism. Promoted naturalistic philosophy.

materialism.critiques: Struggles to explain consciousness and subjective experience, accusations of reductionism
materialism.followers: Estimated 100+ million influenced by materialist worldviews (implicit in many scientists)
materialism.response: Understanding material reality through science explains all phenomena
materialism.overview: Philosophy asserting that physical matter is fundamental reality. Rejects immaterial substances and emphasizes scientific materialism. Foundation for scientific worldview.

branches.name: Scientific Materialism
branches.description: Matter is fundamental, all phenomena reducible to physical processes

branches.name: Dialectical Materialism
branches.description: Marxist materialism emphasizing conflict and historical development

idealism.name: Idealism (Philosophical)
idealism.description: Worldview asserting that reality is fundamentally mental, mind-dependent, or composed of ideas/consciousness

figures.name: Immanuel Kant
figures.significance: German philosopher who developed 'transcendental idealism' - mind structures experience through categories and forms of intuition. Reality as we know it is mind-dependent, though things-in-themselves exist.

figures.name: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel
figures.significance: German philosopher who argued reality is the unfolding of Absolute Spirit/Idea through dialectical process. History is rational development of consciousness and freedom. Influenced Marx and modern thought.

figures.name: George Berkeley
figures.significance: Irish philosopher who argued that material objects are collections of ideas perceived by minds. 'To be is to be perceived.' Challenged materialism through idealism.

coreConcepts: Reality is fundamentally mental or consciousness-based
Mind or ideas are primary reality
Reality unfolds through thought and ideas
idealism.critiques: Difficulty explaining physical world independence, appears disconnected from scientific understanding
idealism.followers: Estimated 10+ million adherents in philosophy and consciousness studies
idealism.response: Mind and consciousness are fundamental to understanding reality
idealism.overview: Philosophy asserting that reality is fundamentally mental or experiential. Emphasizes mind, consciousness, and ideas as primary. Challenges purely physical understanding of existence.

empiricism.name: Empiricism
empiricism.description: Philosophical view that knowledge comes primarily from sensory experience and observation rather than innate ideas

figures.name: John Locke
figures.significance: English philosopher who argued mind begins as 'blank slate' (tabula rasa) and knowledge comes from sensory experience. Championed empirical method and individual rights.
figures.legacy: Founded empiricism, influenced political philosophy and democracy
famous_quotes: Reading furnishes the mind only with materials of knowledge

figures.name: David Hume
figures.significance: Scottish philosopher who radically applied empiricism, arguing that causality, God, and even self are not empirically verifiable. Challenged metaphysical assumptions through skeptical empiricism.
figures.legacy: Influenced Kant and logical positivism, questioning causality
famous_quotes: Beauty is no quality in things themselves: it exists merely in the mind

figures.name: Francis Bacon
figures.significance: English philosopher who promoted 'inductive method' - observation of nature to derive principles. Founded modern scientific method emphasizing experimentation over pure reasoning.

empiricism.critiques: Problem of induction (can't prove universal truths from observations), difficulty accounting for abstract knowledge
empiricism.followers: Estimated 50+ million influenced by empiricist epistemology (implicit in science)
empiricism.response: Scientific observation and experience provide reliable knowledge of the world
empiricism.overview: Philosophy emphasizing knowledge comes from sensory experience. Skeptical of innate ideas and emphasizes observation and experimentation. Foundation of scientific method.

branches.name: Classical Empiricism
branches.description: Hume and Locke emphasizing sensory experience as foundation of knowledge

branches.name: Logical Empiricism
branches.description: Modern empiricism combining logic and verification principle

rationalism.name: Rationalism
rationalism.description: Philosophical view that reason and logic are the primary sources of knowledge, not sensory experience

figures.name: René Descartes
figures.significance: French philosopher who founded modern rationalism. Advocated methodical doubt and reason as path to certain knowledge. Famous for 'Cogito, ergo sum' (I think, therefore I am).
figures.legacy: Founder of modern philosophy, mathematical method in philosophy
famous_quotes: It is not enough to have a good mind, the main thing is to use it well

figures.name: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
figures.significance: German philosopher and mathematician who developed rationalist system emphasizing innate ideas and pre-established harmony. Invented calculus and monadology.

figures.name: Baruch Spinoza
figures.significance: Dutch philosopher who developed rationalist metaphysics with Substance (God/Nature) as fundamental reality. Pantheist who used geometric/mathematical reasoning for philosophy.

coreConcepts: Reason is primary source of knowledge
Mind has access to universal truths
rationalism.critiques: Disconnected from empirical reality, difficulty explaining sensory experience, reliance on unproven assumptions
rationalism.followers: Estimated 30+ million influenced by rationalist philosophy (mathematics, logic, AI)
rationalism.response: Pure reason and logic reveal the fundamental nature of reality
rationalism.overview: Philosophy emphasizing reason and intellect as primary sources of knowledge. Values mathematical and logical thinking. Celebrates human reason's ability to understand reality.

pragmatism.name: Pragmatism
pragmatism.description: Philosophical movement valuing practical consequences and usefulness over abstract truth or theory

figures.name: William James
figures.significance: American psychologist and philosopher who championed pragmatism. Argued truth should be judged by practical consequences and workability. Emphasized action and experience.

figures.name: Charles Sanders Peirce
figures.significance: American philosopher who originated pragmatism and semiotics. Argued meaning and truth emerge through community inquiry and practical experience. Influenced scientific methodology.

figures.name: John Dewey
figures.significance: American philosopher who applied pragmatism to education, democracy, and social reform. Emphasized learning through doing and solving real-world problems. Influenced modern education.

coreConcepts: Truth is what works in practice
pragmatism.critiques: May reduce truth to mere utility, difficulty defining 'works', may ignore principles
pragmatism.followers: Estimated 50+ million influenced by pragmatism (business, education, science)
pragmatism.response: The truth and value of ideas should be measured by their practical consequences
pragmatism.overview: Philosophy judging truth and value by practical consequences and usefulness. Emphasizes action, experimentation, and adaptation. Practical approach to solving problems.

astrology.name: Astrology
astrology.description: Ancient system of interpreting celestial bodies and their influence on human affairs and personality

figures.name: Ptolemy
figures.significance: Greek-Egyptian astronomer who systematized astrology in 'Tetrabiblos'. Established foundations of Western astrology that influenced practice for 1500+ years.
figures.legacy: Foundation of Western astrology for 1500+ years

figures.name: Nostradamus
figures.significance: French astrologer famous for prophecies written in quatrains. Influenced modern astrology and divination practices.
figures.legacy: Famous for prophecies, modern astrology icon

astrology.history: Originated in Babylonia c. 3000 BCE; systematized by Greeks and Ptolemy; spread through Islamic Golden Age; revived during Renaissance; modern astrology combines ancient and contemporary practices
astrology.overview: Ancient practice interpreting celestial movements to understand human affairs and personality. Uses zodiac signs, planetary positions, and birth charts. Blends mythology, mathematics, and psychology.

houses.name: House of Self
houses.meaning: Self-image, personality, appearance, first impressions, identity, how others perceive you

houses.name: House of Possessions
houses.meaning: Money, finances, material possessions, self-worth, values, earning ability

houses.name: House of Communication
houses.meaning: Communication, siblings, short trips, learning, thinking patterns, writing

houses.name: House of Home & Family
houses.meaning: Home, family, roots, parents, foundations, private life, real estate

houses.name: House of Pleasure
houses.meaning: Creativity, romance, children, hobbies, entertainment, self-expression, fun

houses.name: House of Health
houses.meaning: Health, work, daily routines, service, pets, habits, employment

houses.name: House of Partnership
houses.meaning: Marriage, partnerships, relationships, contracts, open enemies, balance

houses.name: House of Transformation
houses.meaning: Shared resources, inheritance, sexuality, death/rebirth, transformation, psychology

houses.name: House of Philosophy
houses.meaning: Higher education, philosophy, religion, travel, publishing, foreign cultures

houses.name: House of Career
houses.meaning: Career, public image, authority, achievement, reputation, social status

houses.name: House of Friendships
houses.meaning: Friendships, groups, hopes, wishes, networking, community, ideals

houses.name: House of Spirituality
houses.meaning: Spirituality, unconscious, hidden matters, solitude, karma, transcendence

aspects.meaning: Blending of energies, unity, combined force, emphasis, powerful influence

aspects.name: Sextile
aspects.meaning: Harmony, ease, opportunity, supportive flow, natural talent

aspects.name: Opposition
aspects.meaning: Polarity, awareness, relationship dynamics, push-pull, integration needed

aspects.name: Quincunx
aspects.meaning: Adjustment, minor tension, need for adaptation, awkwardness

planets.meaning: Core identity, ego, will, vitality, life force, central purpose, conscious self

planets.name: Moon
planets.meaning: Emotions, instincts, subconscious, nurturing, inner world, comfort, habits

planets.name: Mercury
planets.meaning: Communication, thinking, intellect, speech, perception, learning, short trips

planets.name: Venus

planets.name: Mars

planets.name: Jupiter

planets.name: Saturn
planets.meaning: Limitations, discipline, karma, responsibility, time, structure, maturity

planets.name: Uranus
planets.meaning: Revolution, innovation, rebellion, sudden change, freedom, technology

planets.name: Neptune
planets.meaning: Dreams, illusions, spirituality, imagination, mysticism, transcendence

planets.name: Pluto
planets.meaning: Transformation, power, depth, rebirth, death/renewal, the underworld

types.name: Western Astrology (Tropical)
types.key_difference: Based on the spring equinox (vernal point). The zodiac begins at 0° Aries when the sun reaches the spring equinox, regardless of where the actual constellations are.
types.characteristics: Most commonly used in the Western world. Focuses on psychological and personal development. Uses the spring equinox as the fixed starting point.
types.house_system: Multiple systems (Placidus, Whole Sign, Equal, Koch, etc.)
types.strengths: Predictable, mathematically consistent, psychologically focused, widely available resources

types.name: Vedic Astrology (Sidereal)
types.key_difference: Uses actual constellation positions in the sky. Accounts for precession (wobble in Earth's axis). The zodiac is aligned with where constellations actually are, about 24 degrees behind Western astrology.
types.characteristics: Emphasizes karma, reincarnation, and dharma. More precise with current sky positions. Focuses on spiritual growth and past-life influences.
types.strengths: Astronomically accurate, spiritual focus, ancient philosophical foundation, accounts for precession
types.followers: ~500 million (primarily in India and Asia, growing worldwide)

types.name: Hellenistic Astrology
types.key_difference: Foundation for modern Western astrology. Emphasizes horary astrology (answering specific questions) and nativity charts. More mathematical and logical approach.
types.characteristics: Uses aspects, dignities, and rulerships. Focuses on fate and determinism. Highly technical and calculation-based.
types.strengths: Historical foundation, technical precision, detailed rulership systems, influential on modern practice

types.name: Medical Astrology
types.key_difference: Links zodiac signs and planets to body parts and health conditions. Uses astrological timing for medical treatments.
types.characteristics: Each sign governs specific body parts. Planets represent diseases. Moon represents bodily fluids. Practices herbal remedies based on planetary hours.
types.strengths: Holistic health approach, connects cosmos to body, historical medical framework, preventative focus
types.followers: Holistic health practitioners, herbalists, alternative medicine practitioners

types.name: Horary Astrology
types.zodiac_system: Can use either Tropical or Sidereal
types.key_difference: Answers specific yes/no or how/why questions by casting a chart at the moment the question is asked. Not about the person's birth chart.
types.characteristics: Extremely precise timing needed. Uses strict rules and dignities. Focuses on the Quesited (answer) and Querent (questioner). Very practical and answer-focused.
types.strengths: Answers specific questions, practical application, doesn't require birth time, historically proven accurate

types.name: Electional Astrology
types.key_difference: Chooses the best astrological time to START an event (like a wedding, business launch, surgery). Works in reverse - picking optimal timing.
types.characteristics: Identifies favorable planetary alignments for future events. Uses dignity and aspect analysis. Seeks to maximize success probability.
types.strengths: Practical planning tool, maximizes success potential, backed by historical precedent, empowering
types.followers: Event planners, business owners, practitioners seeking optimal timing

types.name: Psychological Astrology
types.key_difference: Uses astrology as a psychological tool for self-understanding and personal growth rather than prediction. Influenced by Jungian psychology.
types.characteristics: Focuses on archetypes, shadow work, and personal integration. Emphasizes free will over fate. Uses birth chart for psychological insight.
types.strengths: Empowering personal growth focus, evidence-based psychology integration, modern relevance, therapeutic applications
types.followers: Therapists, life coaches, self-help seekers, modern practitioners

types.name: Evolutionary Astrology
types.key_difference: Views astrology through the lens of soul evolution and spiritual growth. Uses Pluto placements and nodes heavily. Focuses on transformation and karmic lessons.
types.characteristics: Emphasizes South Node (past/karma) and North Node (future/growth). Sees challenges as growth opportunities. Spiritual and transformative focus.
types.strengths: Spiritual growth orientation, transformative perspective, karmic understanding, healing-focused
types.followers: Spiritual seekers, therapists, coaches with spiritual orientation

types.name: Chinese Astrology
types.key_difference: Based on lunar calendar and 12-year cycles instead of 12-month zodiac. Uses Five Elements (Wu Xing): Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, Water.
types.characteristics: Animal signs repeat every 12 years. Elements cycle every 5 years. Creates 60-year cycles. Focuses on harmony and balance rather than personality types.
types.house_system: No house system - uses elemental interactions
types.strengths: Lunar cycle accuracy, elemental balance philosophy, Taoist principles, practical yearly guidance

types.name: Karmic Astrology
types.key_difference: Interprets birth chart as a blueprint of soul's karmic journey. Uses nodes of the Moon (South = past karma, North = future destiny) as central indicators.
types.characteristics: Every planetary placement represents karmic lessons. Saturn shows karmic challenges. South Node shows innate talents/past abilities. North Node shows soul's direction.
types.strengths: Spiritual framework, karmic understanding, healing-oriented, purpose-focused, growth-directed
types.followers: Spiritual practitioners, reincarnation believers, karmic seekers

variations.name: Western Astrology
variations.description: Tropical zodiac system based on spring equinox, psychologically-focused

variations.name: Vedic Astrology
variations.description: Sidereal system using actual constellation positions, karma-focused

variations.name: Chinese Astrology
variations.description: Animal signs and five elements, lunar calendar based

tarot.name: Tarot
tarot.description: Divination system using a deck of 78 cards with symbolic imagery for insight, guidance, and spiritual exploration
tarot.founded: c. 1440 CE (Italy, as card game; divination use c. 1700s)

figures.name: Antoine Court de Gébelin
figures.significance: French occultist who first connected tarot cards to ancient Egyptian wisdom and popularized tarot for divination purposes in the 18th century.
figures.legacy: Transformed tarot from card game to divination tool

figures.name: Arthur Edward Waite
figures.significance: Created the Rider-Waite tarot deck (1909), one of the most popular and influential tarot decks. Revolutionized tarot with detailed symbolic imagery on minor arcana.
figures.students: Millions of tarot practitioners using his deck
figures.legacy: Created most popular tarot deck (Rider-Waite-Smith)

tarot.followers: 50+ million tarot enthusiasts and practitioners worldwide
tarot.history: Originated as Italian playing cards (tarocchi) c. 1440; used for divination from 18th century onwards; popularized in 19th-20th centuries; modern resurgence in spiritual communities
tarot.overview: Divination system using 78 cards to gain insight and guidance. Features Major and Minor Arcana representing different life aspects. Emphasizes synchronicity, intuition, and self-reflection.

variations.name: Marseille Tarot
variations.description: Traditional French tarot with rich symbolism and esoteric meanings

variations.name: Rider-Waite Tarot
variations.description: Modern tarot with detailed illustrated Minor Arcana cards

variations.name: Thoth Tarot
variations.description: Hermetic tarot combining Egyptian symbolism and Kabbalah

numerology.name: Numerology
numerology.description: Spiritual system interpreting numbers and their vibrations as guides to understanding personality, destiny, and life patterns
numerology.founded: Ancient (used by Pythagoras c. 600 BCE); formalized c. 1400s CE

figures.name: Pythagoras
figures.significance: Ancient Greek mathematician and mystic who believed numbers held sacred significance. Foundation of numerological thought based on mathematical harmony.
figures.legacy: Foundation of numerological thinking

figures.name: L. Dow Balliett
figures.significance: Early 20th century numerologist who systematized and popularized numerology in modern form, writing influential books on the subject.
figures.legacy: Modern numerology framework still used today

soulUrgeNumbers: Calculated from vowels in birth name
Shows what the soul yearns to express
numerology.followers: 30+ million numerology practitioners and believers worldwide
numerology.history: Ancient roots in Hebrew Kabbalah (Gematria) and Pythagorean philosophy; formalized in modern spirituality; blends mathematics with metaphysics
numerology.overview: Mystical practice assigning spiritual significance to numbers. Analyzes birth dates, names, and patterns. Seeks universal meaning through numerical relationships.

variations.name: Pythagorean Numerology
variations.description: Western system based on Greek philosophy and mathematical principles

variations.name: Chaldean Numerology
variations.description: Ancient Babylonian system using different number-letter correspondences

shamanism.name: Shamanism
shamanism.description: Ancient spiritual practice involving direct communication with spirits through trance, ritual, and healing for community wellbeing

figures.name: Mircea Eliade
figures.significance: Comparative religionist who extensively studied and documented shamanic traditions worldwide. His research brought shamanism to academic and Western spiritual attention.
figures.legacy: Legitimized shamanism as serious spiritual practice

figures.name: Don Juan Matus
figures.significance: Famous shaman whose teachings were documented by anthropologist Carlos Castaneda, popularizing shamanism in Western culture.
figures.students: Documented by Carlos Castaneda, influenced millions
figures.legacy: Brought shamanic teachings to Western consciousness

shamansRoles: Healer - treating illness and spiritual imbalance
Keeper of traditions - preserving cultural knowledge
Bridge - connecting physical and spiritual worlds
shamanism.followers: Millions of indigenous practitioners plus growing Western neo-shamanic communities
shamanism.history: Oldest spiritual practice, documented in cultures across Siberia, Americas, Africa, and Asia. Core practices unchanged for thousands of years; modern revival in Western spirituality
shamanism.overview: Ancient spiritual practice found in indigenous cultures worldwide. Shamans act as healers, guides, and intermediaries with spiritual realm. Emphasizes trance, plant medicine, and communion with spirits.

variations.name: Siberian Shamanism
variations.description: Traditional form emphasizing drum journeys and spirit communication

variations.name: Core Shamanism
variations.description: Modern synthesized form accessible to contemporary practitioners

kabbalah.name: Kabbalah
kabbalah.description: Jewish mystical tradition exploring hidden meanings in sacred texts and cosmic structures for spiritual enlightenment and transformation
kabbalah.founded: c. 1200 CE (written form); oral traditions much older

figures.name: Isaac Luria
figures.significance: 16th century kabbalist who developed comprehensive kabbalistic system (Lurianic Kabbalah). His teachings revolutionized mystical Judaism.
figures.legacy: Most influential Kabbalistic system

figures.name: Gershom Scholem
figures.significance: Modern scholar who systematically studied and documented Kabbalah traditions, making them accessible to academic and Western audiences.
figures.legacy: Brought Kabbalah into academic study

kabbalah.followers: Millions of Jewish practitioners plus Western esoteric students
kabbalah.history: Rooted in ancient Jewish mysticism; formalized in medieval Spain; systematized by Luria in 16th century; integrated into Western occultism
kabbalah.overview: Jewish mystical tradition exploring divine nature and cosmic structure. Uses Tree of Life as spiritual map. Emphasizes meditation, Hebrew letter mysticism, and spiritual ascent.

variations.name: Lurianic Kabbalah
variations.description: Eastern Kabbalah emphasizing creation through divine contraction

variations.name: Hermetic Kabbalah
variations.description: Western Kabbalah combining Jewish mysticism with Western occultism

wicca.name: Wicca & Modern Witchcraft
wicca.description: Contemporary pagan spiritual practice honoring nature, divinity (often as goddess and god), and magic for healing and harmony

figures.name: Gerald Gardner
figures.significance: Created and popularized modern Wicca as organized religion in 1950s. Established core rituals, beliefs, and practices that define contemporary Wicca.
figures.students: All Wiccan practitioners follow his framework
figures.legacy: Father of modern Wicca

figures.name: Doreen Valiente
figures.significance: High priestess who created the iconic Charge of the Goddess, defining Wiccan theology and liturgy. Major influence on modern Wicca's spiritual foundation.
figures.legacy: Heart of Wiccan spirituality

wiccaBeliefs: Reverence for nature and natural cycles
Divinity as Goddess and God (or both)
wicca.history: Emerged in 1950s England; rapidly spread globally; diverse traditions developed; combines witchcraft, paganism, and goddess spirituality
wicca.overview: Modern pagan spiritual movement celebrating nature, Goddess/God, and magic. Emphasizes seasonal cycles, personal power, and harm to none. Ritual-based practice honoring natural forces.

variations.name: Gardnerian Wicca
variations.description: Original tradition founded by Gerald Gardner with strict initiatory lineage

variations.name: Alexandrian Wicca
variations.description: Branch of Gardnerian Wicca with similar practices and initiatory structure

variations.name: Eclectic Wicca
variations.description: Modern non-initiatory form allowing personal interpretation and practice
